abstract: Conflict in Congo can be seen as 'Africa's first world war'; six outside states are fighting inside Congo alone, battling for bewildering number of reasons; some armies are allied with rebel groups to oust Pres Laurent Kabila; others are protecting him; some groups are fighting to overthrow governments in neighboring countries; nearly everyone carts off Congo's natural riches, which include diamonds, oil, uranium and gold; some experts argue that war in Congo is actually three wars: first is battle between Kabila and Congolese rebels fighting to overthrow him; second is ethnic war, primarily against Congolese Tutsi; third involves outside countries: Rwanda and Uganda on side of rebels, Zimbabwe, Angola and Namibia on Kabila's side; country by country look at wars; photos; maps (L)

headline: DIAMOND WARS: A special report.; Africa's Gems: Warfare's Best Friend
snippet: The rough stone emerges from the African soil at fortresslike mines in the war zones of Angola or straight from the muck of a dammed-up river in Congo. After journeying across continents and oceans, after being graded, cut, polished and set in gold...
subjects: [u'SURVEYS AND SERIES', u'PRICES (FARES, FEES AND RATES)', u'DIAMONDS']
abstract: Portability and anonymity of diamonds have made them currency of choice for those waging wars in various countries in Africa (special report, Diamond Wars); diamonds from African war zones reportedly accounted for 10 to 15 percent of world suppply as recently as mid-1990's; Americans buy more than half the world's diamond jewelry, and diamond sales around world are booming; De Beers, South African conglomerate that controls two-thirds of world's rough diamonds, showed record sales last year of more than $5 billion; smugglers in Sierra Leone and Congo have ready access to third of world diamond market that De Beers does not control; diamonds spilling out of Angola's war zone have had destabilizing effect on De Beers cartel; its reputation has been tarred by reports that it bought up sizable amount of diamonds from Unita rebels to maintain world prices; photos; map (L)

headline: Israel Is Slowly Shedding Harsh Treatment of Arabs
snippet: Justice Minister Yossi Beilin calls it a ''quiet revolution.''     Through the years, Israel has been consistently criticized by many human and civil rights organizations for invoking national security to explain practices that were considered...
subjects: [u'PALESTINIANS', u'DISCRIMINATION', u'ARABS', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS']
abstract: Crucial policy changes and spate of High Court decisions regarding Israel's treatment of Israeli Arabs and Palestinians have occurred since right-wing government was replaced last summer by broad coalition including several leftists and human rights advocates; through the years, Israel has been consistently criticized by many human rights and civil rights orgns for invoking national security to explain practices that were considered exclusionary, discriminatory and coercive toward Israeli Arabs and Palestinians; torture of Palestinian suspects has been banned; practice of stripping Palestinians of their residency rights in East Jerusalem has all but ended; in a landmark ruling, equal right of Arabs to land allocated by state has been affirmed; and for first time in Israel's history, land long considered part of a Jewish town was taken away and returned to Arab village from which it was expropriated decades ago; photo (M)

abstract: Spread of mob killings in Cambodia in past year is one of many signs of failure of justice system that United Nations tried to put in place nearly decade ago; police officers say they find lynchings and beatings of wrongdoers short-cut around vagaries of courts; this has led most experts to agree that Cambodian courts are unfit to conduct fair and professional tribunal for men who led Khmer Rouge from 1975 to 1979, when more than million people lost their lives; United Nations, which proposed to create international court, has reached impasse with Prime Min Hun Sen, who insists that Cambodian prosecutors and judges dominate any tribunal; photo (M)

headline: Neighbors Grab Fugitive Rebel In Sierra Leone

abstract: Foday Sankoh, Sierra Leone rebel leader who vanished nine days ago, is captured at his house in Freetown by pro-government militia tipped off by Sankoh's neighbors; Sankoh was last seen after his bodyguards killed 19 demonstrators outside his house, and after he dealt humiliating blows to United Nations peacekeeping force, taking 500 of them hostage; Sankoh is in custody of Sierra Leone's government and is being protected by British paratroopers; his capture ends days of intense speculation about his whereabouts, and it raises issue of what to do with him; his forces are responsible for wave of terror in 1998 and 1999 when they killed, raped and hacked off limbs of thousands of citizens; Sankoh was granted amnesty in peace accord signed in July 1999, in exchange for ending his violent campaign against Pres Ahmed Tejan Kabbah; photo; map (M)

headline: At Life's End, Many Patients Are Denied Peaceful Passing
snippet: At the age of 91, Bertha Hyman had a clear mind and a firm resolve. When her life neared its end, she wanted no heroic measures: no resuscitation, no respirator, no tangle of tubes. She signed a ''living will'' outlining her wishes, informed two...
subjects: [u'STATES (US)', u'SURVEYS AND SERIES', u'DEATH AND DYING', u'SUITS AND LITIGATION', u'ETHICS', u'AGED', u'LIFE-SUSTAINING SUPPORT SYSTEMS, WITHDRAWAL OF', u'LAW AND LEGISLATION', u'LIVING WILLS']
abstract: First of two articles on Planning for Death describes plight of many old people who are denied their wish for peaceful death without heroic medical measures, even though they had signed 'living wills' outlining that wish; Sabena Wilensky and Rosalind Keyes recall anguish at being unable to stop doctors from putting 91-year-old aunt Bertha Hyman on respirator, because Florida nursing home had not sent her living will or power-of-attorney to hospital; such advance directives often fail because they are lost or forgotten or too vague for relatives or legally-minded hospitals to interpret, or because they are overruled by doctors who refuse to stop treatment; some experts believe very concept is flawed because illness is too unpredictable to be anticipated by simple document; widespread gaps and deficiencies in care of the dying discussed, along with devastating effects on patients and loved ones; photos; maps showing legality of living wills and do-not-resuscitate orders (M)

abstract: US labor movement is again powerful political force, despite loss in bruising battle over China trade bill; : provided important political muscle that helped Vice Pres Al Gore lock up Democratic presidential nomination, and is certain to be major force for Democratic Party in fall; has displayed considerable political muscle on Capitol Hill, blocking legislation to grant President fast-track authority to negotiate trade agreements and pushing through higher minimum-wage and Family and Medical Leave Act; white-collar workers are flocking into unions as never before, and much of rebound is attributed to efforts of AFL-CIO president John J Sweeney, who was elected in 1996 on platform of reviving labor after membership and influence slipped steadily for two decades; union membership jumped 265,000 in 1999, by far largest rise since 1970's; photo (M)

headline: The World: Playing by the Rules; From an Old-Fashioned War, a Very Modern Calamity

subjects: [u'WAR CRIMES AND CRIMINALS', u'FAMINE']
abstract: Border war between Ethiopia and Eritrea is noteworthy because African states have generally observed Organization of African Unity's prohibition on warring against each other and also because both sides have generally observed recognized rules of war in old-fashioned sort of stand-up fight; civilian casualties from combat have been limited and neither side has accused the other of gross violations of human rights; such restrained conduct is of small comfort to the millions of civilians who face starvation as side effect of the war; photo (M)

subjects: [u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES', u'SEX CRIMES', u'CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS', u'TORTURE']
abstract: Massacre in tiny village of El Salado highlights United States and human rights groups' reservations about Colombia's military leadership, its human rights record and its collaboration with paramilitary units; more then 300 armed men marched into village in February, and with list of names began summoning residents for judgment; troops ordered liquor and music, then embarked on calculated three-day rampage of torture, rape and killing of scores of people they accused of collaborating with left-wing guerrillas who have long been presence in area; military and police units just few miles away not only made no effort to stop slaughter, but also set up roadblock, preventing human rights groups from getting to village; while military has opened three investigations into massacre, top officials insist that fighting was under way in village between guerrillas and paramilitary forces, not a series of executions; they also insist that colonel in charge of region, Rodrigo Quinones Cardenas, who has since been promoted to general, has been persecuted by government and human rights groups; map; photos (L)

abstract: Special report, Young and Condemned, on youthful offenders awaiting executions on death rows across America; 80 current cases comprise small percentage of all inmates on death row, but represent larger number of youthful offenders awaiting execution than at any other time since ban on capital punishment was lifted in 1978; only handful of such executions have been carried out in 23 of 38 states that have death penalty, underscoring complex attitudes about capital punishment in US; even many prosecutors who support death penalty, as well as national organizations neutral on issue, are concerned about sentencing to death those who were still children when crimes were committed; US is only one of seven countries that permit such executions, and one of two nations lax in ratifying lanugage prohibiting practice which is included in several humnan rights treaties, including UN Convention on the Rights of the Child; landmark 1989 Supreme Court decision upholding constitutionality of death penalty for 16- and 17-year-olds noted; case of Alexander Williams, who awaits execution on August 24 for murder committed in 1986 when he was 17, discussed; photos (L)

subjects: [u'TAX EVASION', u'TAXATION', u'TRANSPLANTS', u'CAPITAL PUNISHMENT']
abstract: Hundreds, perhaps thousands, of condemned people in China have their organs 'harvested' minutes after their death by gunshot to back of head; China executes more people each year than rest of world combined, although exact number is tightly guarded state secret; Amnesty International counted 18,194 executions reported in state-run press in 1990's, with 1,263 in 1999; some scholars and human rights advocates contend real total is much higher because many executions are never reported; many of the executed become organ donors; practice is permitted under 1994 rules, but only with written consent of prisoner or his or her relatives; whether most condemned prisoners donate their organs willingly is matter of debate; Buddhist and Confucian beliefs dictate that body be kept whole after death, meaning that voluntary donations are rare; China is again in throes of campaign against tax evasion that has already led to death sentences for many people; one man discusses inequities in case of his brother, who was executed for tax evasion and had his organs removed (L)

headline: Memos Point to Ties Between Auction Houses
snippet: Handwritten memos at the center of the collusion case of Christie's and Sotheby's auction houses suggest that the companies secretly altered time-honored and costly inducements used to attract sellers. Acting together, they dropped low-interest...
subjects: [u'ANTITRUST ACTIONS AND LAWS', u'AUCTIONS', u'ART']
abstract: Handwritten memos at center of collusion case of Christie's and Sotheby's auction houses suggest companies secretly altered time-honored and costly inducements used to attract sellers; memos indicate that acting together, they dropped low-interest loans, ceased making donations to sellers' favorite charities and devised system to increase their profits when art sold above guaranteed minumum; documents also indicate that houses devised other ways to cooperate behind scenes by not poaching each other's employees and not speaking ill of each other in front of clients; arrangements paint picture of competitors operating not as cutthroat rivals but almost as cozy partners, consulting each other to detriment of their customers; papers are given to federal prosecutors by Christie's, which cooperated with antitrust investigation; they suggest top Christie's officials were keenly aware of law and believed they could skirt it; case now focuses on recent indictments of Sir Anthony Tennant, former Christie's chairman, and his counterpart at Sotheby's, A Alfred Taubman; one crucial memo, allegedly from Tennant, appears to instruct Christopher M Davidge, then second in command to Tennant, to work with his counterpart at Sotheby's, Diana D Brooks, to firm up wide-ranging agreement; photos (L)

abstract: China has made great strides in enforcing rule of law for commercial transactions, particularly those involving foreigners, but it still deals with criminal behavior in same brutal way it has for centuries, by occasionally singling out suspect for severe punishment, usually execution; some criminal practices are considered only moderately risky, but there is always threat of death for unlucky few at ever-shifting perimeter of tolerance, and there is often randomness in who dies; Beijing has carried out since 1983 periodic campaigns to eliminate changing list of crimes that have resulted in tens of thousands of executions, or more each year than rest of world combined; Amnesty International reports at least 4,367 executions during 1996 campaign, or about dozen each day; says government is in midst of new anti-corruption drive, and that executions that had subsided are again on rise; executions of Jin Ruchao, accused of blowing up four buildings in March, and Hao Fengqin, who unwittingly sold explosives to Jin discussed; both were executed approximately month after arrests in Beibaisha; map; photos (M)

subjects: [u'WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC)', u'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'PENTAGON BUILDING', u'MISSING PERSONS', u'HIJACKING', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: US steps up efforts to persuade Afghan people to turn over Osama bin Laden, with American military aircraft broadcasting radio message announcing $25 million cash reward for information leading to his location or capture; broadcasts, which identify other leaders of Al Qaeda terrorist organization thought to be hiding in Afghanistan, are latest element of US strategy to rely heavily on anti-Taliban rebels and other Afghans to help reveal whereabouts; Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld stresses special operations forces will not mount cave-by-cave hunt, but will continue applying pressure by setting up roadblocks and gathering intelligence; suggests US will rely more heavily on bombing raids and anti-Taliban Afghan forces; US warplanes carry out heavy strikes around Taliban stronghold of Kandahar; Rumsfeld says Taliban's leader, Mullah Mohammad Omar, will not be allowed to negotiate his escape from city and that seeking asylum in foreign country or receiving amnesty within Afghanistan will not be acceptable to US; in addition to radio broadcasts, warplanes are dropping thousands of leaflets in Afghanistan asking for help in hunting bin Laden; photo (M)

abstract: Northern Alliance official says foreign militants trapped in besieged city of Kunduz have asked for safe passage out of Afghanistan to Pakistan; Taliban and alliance are discussing surrender of Kunduz; map;Sec Donald Rumsfeld firmly opposes any deal for foreigners that would let them loose in other countries; says they must surrender; Pakistan fears slaughter of its citizens; UN officials, approached by Northern Alliance, say they do not have transport in any case (M)

headline: Fierce Fighting Erupts Near Kunduz, Despite Surrender Deal
snippet: Heavy fighting broke out today between Taliban and Northern Alliance troops along the front lines outside Kunduz as a senior alliance leader said Taliban officials had agreed to surrender the encircled city, where thousands of Taliban troops and...
subjects: [u'WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC)', u'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'HIJACKING', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Heavy fighting breaks out between Taliban and Northern Alliance troops along front lines outside Kunduz as senior alliance leader says Taliban officials have agreed to surrender encircled city; thousands of Taliban troops and foreign soldiers are trapped in city; fierce fighting suggests that Taliban leaders who struck surrender deal might not speak for all rank-and-file soldiers, or even for other commanders; as fighting rages, several Taliban soldiers cross front lines and switch sides, lending air of chaos to scene; peace deal supposedly worked out by Gen Abdul Rashid Dostum, longtime Uzbek warlord, seems fraught with questions; photos (M)

headline: Helping Countries, and People, to Heal

abstract: Northern Alliance soldiers in Afghanistan report Pakistani airplanes have again flown into encircled city of Kunduz to evacuate Pakistanis who had been fighting with Taliban; photo; map; sightings are not confirmed and US officials are evasive on subject; US is indebted to Pakistan for helping with war but also wants foreign fighters captured or killed; surrender of Kunduz is yet unclear; Taliban forces regroup elsewhere, forming strong pockets of resistance in east, including Jalalabad vicinity (M)

headline: SURRENDER OF TALIBAN BEGINS AT FINAL NORTHERN STRONGHOLD
snippet: Hundreds of Taliban soldiers streamed out of the besieged northern city of Kunduz today, some to the welcoming arms of joyous crowds, others to the custody of their adversaries, each group following a script of surrender that culminated a two-week...
subjects: [u'WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC)', u'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'PENTAGON BUILDING', u'MISSING PERSONS', u'HIJACKING', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Hundreds of Taliban soldiers begin surrender of northern stronghold of Kunduz, Afghanistan, culminating two-week standoff in one of last Taliban-held areas; some are welcomed by joyous crowds, others led into detention by adversaries; estimated 700 soldiers who surrender are part of nearly quarter of Taliban garrison, based on Pentagon calculations; Northern Alliance leaders say they believe thousands more remain in area and expect fight to capture city; several Taliban soldiers report many Pakistani and other foreign troops were evacuated in recent days by Pakistani air force planes during night; surrender by Taliban at locations around city described; US warplanes bomb city in apparent warning to soldiers against changing minds; photos (M)

headline: Talking About Trauma
snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Treatment Can Ease Lingering Trauma of Sept. 11'': One factor in the recovery from post-traumatic stress is not mentioned: the continued love and the compassionate support of the victims' families.
subjects: [u'WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC)', u'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', u'HIJACKING', u'MENTAL HEALTH AND DISORDERS', u'POST-TRAUMATIC STRESS DISORDER', u'TERRORISM']
abstract: Kathy King Wouk letter comments on Nov 20 article on post-traumatic stress disorder among people who were close to Sept 11 terrorist attacks; says continued love and compassionate support of victims' families can speed healing

headline: Unsure Ground for Fight Against Atrocity
snippet: The conflict in Afghanistan has posed a broad spectrum of concerns for human rights organizations, not the least of them the absence of credible information from the scene.    The immediate attention has focused on reports of killings of prisoners...
subjects: [u'WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC)', u'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'WAR CRIMES AND CRIMINALS', u'CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE', u'HIJACKING', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Conflict in Afghanistan poses broad spectrum of concerns for human rights organizations, most notably absence of credible information from the scene; reports of killings of prisoners since rout of Taliban are disturbing enough for Mary Robinson, United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, to seek 'clarification'; but no major human rights group has own monitors in country, and in war with few credible witnesses, and some Taliban soldiers clearly fanatical, exact circumstances of killings are murky; Sidney Jones, Asia director for Human Rights Watch, says any summary execution of prisoners violates Geneva Convention; says concern was raised that dozens of dead prisoners in Qala Jangi fort had hands bound, but that does not mean they were summarily executed, and her organization has nobody there to investigate; says it is not even clear whether Geneva Convention applies; fighting in Afghanistan is sort of internationalized civil war that has become increasingly common, but legally complex; map (M)

headline: French Leader Visits Algiers To Shore Up Terrorism War
snippet: President Jacques Chirac of France swept into this port city for an eight-hour visit today, the first time a French president had been to Algeria in more than 12 years.    With President Abdelaziz Bouteflika, Mr. Chirac briefly toured of an area of...
subjects: [u'INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS', u'TERRORISM']
abstract: Pres Jacques Chirac of France visits Algeria to meet with Pres Abdelziz Bouteflika, first time a French president has been to Algeria in more than 12 years; hastily arranged trip is sign that Algerian government, by offering to cooperate with America's war on terrorism, is getting more sympathetic hearing than it has in past; Western governments, including France, are showing less inclination to listen to complaints of international human rights groups and Algerian democracy activists who condemn Algeria for its handling of Islamic militants; Chirac, asked if he had wrongly dismissed Algeria's claims in past that Europe was being used as base for Algerian terrorists, says 'we were wrong'; photo (M)

headline: Spy, Citing Fears, Fights Return to China

subjects: [u'ARMS SALES ABROAD', u'ASYLUM (POLITICAL)', u'DEPORTATION', u'IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES', u'BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION', u'TORTURE']
abstract: Bin Wu, former Chinese spy whose career as double or triple agent ended with his 1992 arrest and conviction for shipping military goods to China, fights deportation to China, where he and Amnesty International say he faces torture and execution; Wu, released in July, is not eligible for asylum because of his felony conviction (M)

headline: U.S. Planes Keep Up Bombing Of Kandahar as Allies Close In

subjects: [u'WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC)', u'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'PENTAGON BUILDING', u'ROYAL FAMILY', u'MISSING PERSONS', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'HIJACKING', u'AMNESTIES AND PARDONS', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: US warplanes resume daily attack on Kandahar, putting more pressure on Taliban stronghold in southern Afghanistan; leaders of Pashtun tribes say forces have takes new ground and are within 10 miles of city; senior Bush administration officials stress US is in talks with anti-Taliban forces to guarantee that Taliban and non-Afghan Al Qaeda commanders, if captured, will be turned over to Americans and not granted amnesty to speed surrender; comments by Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld noted; talks between four Afghan opposition groups for broad power-sharing agreement approach crucial point in Bonn, Germany; draft agreement calls for 28-member executive administration, international security force for capital of Kabul and symbolic role for former king, Mohammed Zahir Shah; Taliban forces, though squeezed by bombardment and opposition attacks, remain firmly entrenched in Kandahar; some pockets of resistance are operating out of region between Jalalabad and Pakistani border; Rumsfeld says between 1,500 and 2,000 American troops are operating in Afghanistan; warns difficult and dangerous months lie ahead as mission changes from attacking massed forces of Taliban and Al Qaeda and rooting out smaller bands of resistance; ongoing US military buildup described; photo (M)

headline: Talks in Bonn End With Deal On Leadership For Afghans
locations: [u'NEW YORK CITY', u'KABUL (AFGHANISTAN)', u'WASHINGTON (DC)', u'AFGHANISTAN', u'KANDAHAR (AFGHANISTAN)']
snippet: After negotiating all night, Afghan delegates reached agreement early this morning on a new, post-Taliban government for Afghanistan that will take power in Kabul on Dec. 22, according to Ahmad Fawzi, a United Nations spokesman.    The interim...
subjects: [u'WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC)', u'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'HIJACKING', u'WOMEN', u'TERRORISM']
abstract: Afghan delegates meeting in Bonn, Germany, reach agreement on new post-Taliban government for Afghanistan that will assume power in Kabul on December 22; interim administration will be led by Hamid Karzai, Pashtun leader currently fighting Taliban in home territory of Kandahar; one of five vice chairmen will be Dr Sima Samar, who will also be in charge of women's affairs; Dr Suhaila Seddiqi will be in charge of public health; other appointees not identified; new administration will be made up of chairman, five deputies and 23 other ministers; will take over country's seat at UN; current administration in Kabul, led by former president Burhanuddin Rabbani, will be supplanted; photos (M)

headline: After Arm-Twisting, Afghan Factions Pick Interim Government and Leader
locations: [u'BONN (GERMANY)', u'GERMANY', u'NEW YORK CITY', u'GREAT BRITAIN', u'RUSSIA', u'INDIA', u'IRAN', u'PAKISTAN', u'FRANCE', u'KABUL (AFGHANISTAN)', u'WASHINGTON (DC)', u'AFGHANISTAN']
snippet: Four Afghan factions signed a pact today creating a broad-based interim government for post-Taliban Afghanistan after more than 20 years of rivalry and warfare causing millions of deaths.    The new government, which is to take power in Kabul on Dec....
subjects: [u'WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC)', u'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'HIJACKING', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Four Afghan factions meeting in Bonn sign pact creating broad-based interim government for post-Taliban Afghanistan that will take power in Kabul on Dec 22 for up to six months; it will be headed by Hamid Karzai, Pashtun tribal leader currently fighting Taliban in southern Afghanistan; his selection is acceptable to various factions inside Afghanistan and to neighboring Pakistan, which has many Pashtuns and has been uncomfortable with non-Pashtun Northern Alliance's control of Kabul since Taliban fled; Northern Alliance will have 17 ministers in Karzai's government, out of total of 30; pact comes after 9 days of negotiations and much prodding by United Nations special envoy, Lakhdar Brahimi, and diplomats from United States, Germany, Britain, France, Russia, India, Iran and Pakistan; Yunus Qanooni, interior minister and leader of Northern Alliance delegation, promises complete cooperation, but officials warn that Northern Alliance's titular head, Burhanuddin Rabbani, and his Pashtun Wahhabi ally, Abdul Rab Rassoul Sayyaf, remain unhappy with deal; negotiators remove two controversial points from earlier drafts to help pacify Rabbani and Sayyaf, but two could work to alter allotment of power during emergency loya jirga, constituent assembly expected to convene in spring; photos (M)

headline: OFFER IS MADE TO SURRENDER TALIBAN'S LAST STRONGHOLD; DEAL MAY HINGE ON AMNESTY
snippet: Surrounded by opposition forces and harried by weeks of American bombing, the Taliban agreed today to surrender the southern city of Kandahar, their last stronghold and the birthplace of their radical Islamic movement.    But tonight negotiators had...
subjects: [u'WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC)', u'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'PENTAGON BUILDING', u'HIJACKING', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Afghan Taliban forces surrounded in Kandahar agree to surrender their last stronghold, but negotiators have yet to resolve crucial issues of fate of leader Muhammad Omar and thousands of Arab fighters loyal to Osama bin Laden; yet uncaptured is bin Laden, who Gen Muhammad Fahim says has retreated to caves of Tora Bora region close to Pakistan frontier; surrender terms call for Omar to cede power to local tribal leader and have soldiers lay down weapons; new Afghan leader Hamid Karzai says Omar and top aides must face trial for crimes, noting that Omar has not even made statement of regret; former Taliban envoy Abdul Salam Zaeef comments in Islamabad; photo; map; intense negotiations and role of various factions detailed (M)

headline: A Cornered Enemy
snippet: The American war aims were clear: Take down the Taliban regime, which had converted Afghanistan into a temple for terrorists, and destroy Al Qaeda, the terror network that operated freely there. The war oratory was sharp: Bring to justice those...
subjects: [u'WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC)', u'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'WAR CRIMES AND CRIMINALS', u'PENTAGON BUILDING', u'PERSIAN GULF WAR', u'HIJACKING', u'FOREIGN AID', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: News analysis on how US can bring Taliban leader Muhammad Omar to justice, one of avowed aims of military campaign in Afghanistan, now that his remaining forces are cornered in Kandahar; Bush administration officials are firmly against allowing Omar voice in his own fate, as happened when first Bush administration left Saddam Hussein in power in Iraq; Sec Donald Rumsfeld scorns talk of 'amnesty' for Omar, even if arranged by new provision leader Hamid Karzai; officials signal that anmesty for senior Taliban figures could end military cooperation and reconstruction aid; Pentagon is willing to allow rank-and-file Taliban to disarm and go back to villages; White House hints at flexibility on just how leaders might be punished (M)

headline: Fall of Kandahar, Debating a Surrender and Firefighters' Suspicions
snippet: Two months after it began, the war in Afghanistan seemed to be coming to a surprisingly rapid end, as Taliban forces agreed to surrender the southern city of Kandahar, their last stronghold. Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban leader who remained in...

abstract: Overview of day's events in war in Afghanistan and summary of antiterror measures at home (M)

headline: TALIBAN ABANDON LAST STRONGHOLD; OMAR IS NOT FOUND
snippet: Two months after the American  bombardment of Afghanistan began, Taliban forces today abandoned their last stronghold in Kandahar.    The surrender, reported by anti-Taliban leaders entering the city, appeared to complete the collapse of the radical...
subjects: [u'WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC)', u'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'HIJACKING', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Taliban forces abandon their last stronghold in Kandahar two months after American bombardment of Afghanistan begins; surrender appears to complete collapse of radical Islamic grou that ruled country; in Kandahar, rival warlords compete for control, some Taliban fighters remain defiant, and fate of Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, is unclear; United States marines attack Taliban troops fleeing Kandahar as hunt for Mullah Omar intensifies; Taliban has fallen from power, but two essential American war aims remain unfulfilled: elimination of accused terrorist Osama bin Laden and capture of Mullah Omar, who harbored him as he defied United States; photos; map (M)

headline: The Taliban Exits
snippet: Wars in Afghanistan don't begin and end with clockwork precision, but the American-led campaign to overthrow the Taliban has succeeded. Though skirmishes may continue in the days ahead, Afghanistan's people can now look forward to a new and more...
subjects: [u'WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC)', u'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'EDITORIALS', u'CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE', u'HIJACKING', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Editorial hails success of American-led drive to overthrow Taliban as war against international terrorism and its extremist protectors; holds Mullah Muhammad Omar and other top Taliban leaders, once captured, should be tried in Afghanistan; urges Pakistan to help prevent Osama bin Laden's escape into Pakistan

headline: Macedonia Donors Meeting Put Off After Dispute on Local Rule
snippet: A donors meeting to provide financing for reform and reconstruction in Macedonia has been put off indefinitely because the government did not fulfill a central part of its peace plan with rebel minority Albanians, diplomats said today.    Tentative...
subjects: [u'FINANCES', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT']
abstract: Donors meeting to provide financing for reform and reconstruction in Macedonia is put off indefinitely because government has not yet enacted local self-government bill, central part of its peace plan with rebel minority Albanians (M)

headline: Justice Without Borders
snippet: Some crimes are so heinous, say legal experts, that they transcend jurisdictional boundaries. People accused of them should be prosecuted anywhere in the world, regardless of where the incident occurred -- and regardless of the nationality of anyone...
subjects: [u'TWO THOUSAND AND ONE (YEAR)', u'WAR CRIMES AND CRIMINALS']
abstract: Scholars and jurists at recent Princeton University conference produce manifesto setting forth how and when court in one country can try foreign national for crimes committed in another; war crimes, crimes against humanity and peace and torture are among those qualifying for universal jurisdiction (The Year in Ideas) (S)

headline: TALIBAN GIVE WAY IN FINAL PROVINCE WHERE THEY RULED
locations: [u'NEW YORK CITY', u'PAKISTAN', u'KABUL (AFGHANISTAN)', u'WASHINGTON (DC)', u'AFGHANISTAN', u'KANDAHAR (AFGHANISTAN)']
snippet: The five-year rule of the Taliban, exceptionally harsh even in a land governed for decades by bloodletting, came to an official end today as the last Afghan province slipped from their control. Their fractious opponents, due to start governing in two...
subjects: [u'WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC)', u'RECORDINGS (VIDEO)', u'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'PENTAGON BUILDING', u'HIJACKING', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Five-year rule of Taliban in Afghanistan ends as province of Kandahar slips from their control; their fractious opponents agree to bury some of many feuds that could jeopardize peace, even as leader Mullah Muhammad Omar and Osama bin Laden continue to elude capture; American B-52's intensify bombardment of complex of caves in eastern Afghanistan where bin Laden is believed in hiding; anti-Taliban commanders near fortified Tora Bora cave complex prepare for major ground assault; US marines in south and army of neighboring Pakistan tighten dragnet on ground; Hamis Karzai, designated leader of interim government scheduled to take power in Kabul on December 22, arrives in Kandahar for first time since surrender was announced on December 6; moves to secure deal and end fighting between two rival anti-Taliban groups; US officials say new evidence is found linking bin Laden to September 11 attacks; confirm Washington Post report that US found videotape showing bin Laden giving detailed description of attacks; Vice Pres Dick Cheney says bin Laden displays significant knowledge of what happened, and that there is no doubt about his responsibility for September 11 terrorist attacks on Washington (DC) and New York City; photos; map (M)

headline: Immigration Hearings

headline: Taliban Gone, but Fear Lingers in Kandahar
snippet: At least 30 American Special Forces soldiers have occupied the inner courtyard of the sprawling house belonging to Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban leader who disappeared once his Islamic militia crumbled, leaving the streets of his stronghold in...
subjects: [u'WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC)', u'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'PENTAGON BUILDING', u'MISSING PERSONS', u'HIJACKING', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Security is iffy in wide areas of Afghanistan as remnants of Taliban units remain in control of large pockets earlier believed captured; fear lingers in Kandahar, cradle of Taliban movement and last major Afghan city wrested from their control; symbols of Taliban rule lay in ruin, and streets are in disarray; US Special Forces soldiers occupy sprawling home of Mullah Muhammad Omar, Taliban leader who disappeared, and militiamen of unknown affiliation roam city, increasing fears of residents; many Afghans venture into streets for first time since Taliban's demise, but scenes of jubilation are few; express worry that anarchy and warlordism will succeed Taliban, just as they preceded mullahs' rule; photo (M)

headline: G.I.'s Had Crucial Role In Battle for Kandahar
snippet: On the morning of Dec. 5, Hamid Karzai, who would be named Afghanistan's new interim leader hours later, was meeting with seven of his closest advisers in a house in Shawalit Kowt, at the foot of a hill 18 miles north of here. The men sat on the...
subjects: [u'WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC)', u'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'PASHTUN (ETHNIC GROUP)', u'HIJACKING', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Details are emerging about crucial war in Kandahar and rest of southern Afghanistan, and central role played by American military; fall of Taliban and rise of Hamid Karzai, who will become interim president on Dec 22, is described as remarkable collaboration of two initially incongruous military partners: willful Afghan tribesmen with ancient enmities and American commandos with lavish technology adapting to new kind of war; unlike war in north, which Northern Alliance was already leading against Taliban before start of US involvement on Oct 7, anti-Taliban movement in south led by Karzai and other Pashtun leaders would likely never have succeeded, or even come together, without United States; chronology; map; photo (M)

headline: The World; In One Muslim Land, an Effort To Enforce Lessons of Tolerance
snippet: MANY Muslims believe that the West is clinging to an ugly image of Islam, one that distorts its basic principles of peace, equality and justice. Yet, it is sometimes in the Muslim world's own schools and media that the religion's message is taught as...
subjects: [u'EDUCATION AND SCHOOLS', u'ISLAM']
abstract: Muslim intolerance of other religions is sometimes inculcated in fundamentalist schools throughout Islamic world, but Tunisia represents rare example of regime that is trying to open up schools to broader, and more tolerant attitudes; taking back the schools--teaching Islam as code of behavior compatible with life in pluralistic and interconnected world--will not be easy; it is just one part of continuing battle against religious extremism in Islamic world; photo (M)

headline: China, in Harsh Crackdown, Executes Muslim Separatists
snippet: A crowd gathered in a sports stadium beneath a blue morning sky here in October to watch court officials sentence a man to death, a scene that has been played out hundreds of times across China this year as part of the Communist Party's latest drive...
subjects: [u'POLITICAL PRISONERS', u'UIGHURS (CHINESE ETHNIC GROUP)', u'CAPITAL PUNISHMENT', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'INDEPENDENCE MOVEMENTS AND SECESSION', u'ISLAM', u'CRIME AND CRIMINALS']
abstract: China is harshly cracking down on Muslim separatists; is executing persons who are part of persistent and occasionally violent separatist movement among China's Uighurs, Turkic-speaking ethnic group of nine million people, most of them Muslims, concentrated along country's far western border; fragile, fertile strip between China's rugged western mountains and its vast western desert is only place in country where people are regularly put to death for political offenses; Uighurs say that country's current anticrime drive, coupled with renewed focus on Islamic militancy in wake of American-led war on terrorism, has only increased pace of executions; photos; map (L)

headline: For Afghan Leader, American Support of Another Sort

abstract: Cambodians feel betrayed and abandoned after United Nations gives up effort to create international tribunal to try former leaders of Khmer Rouge; UN ended nearly five years of negotiations over makeup and procedures of tribunal, worn down by stubbornness of Cambodian government; this leaves government to proceed on its own with trials that both Cambodian and foreign analysts say will not meet international standards of fairness and impartiality and are likely to spare most major figures; Khmer Rouge, led by late Pol Pot, were responsible for deaths of more than million people when they held power from 1975 to 1979 (M)

headline: Backing Reporter, Russian Court Rejects Another Secrecy Law

abstract: Russia's Supreme Court hands legal victory to Grigory Pasko, military journalist fighting treason conviction; strikes down Soviet-era edict barring many servicemen from unapproved contacts with foreigners; ruling comes day after same court invalidates 1996 order establishing sweeping categories of military secrecy; Pasko's lawyer says two rulings demolish claim that his client conspired to commit espionage in mid-1990's when he helped Japanese journalists document Russian Navy's mishandling of nuclear waste; Pasko has spent 22 months in jail, rejecting both amnesty and broad hints of pardon; case has become international cause for human rights activists and embarrassment for Kremlin (M)

abstract: Senior Pakistani officials say government will expel thousands of Arab, Afghan and other foreign students now studying at religious schools across country, out of concern that their presence might be step toward possible militant activities; plan would also bar new enrollment of foreign students altogether; plan stems from promise made by Gen Pervez Musharraf in Jan to deport foreign students at madrassas who lacked valid visas; in past, Pakistan's government allowed madrassas to operate virtually unregulated; madrassas served as principal base for Islamic scholars who became leaders of Taliban movement in Afghanistan and fighters against American-led forces there; government also intends to release at least 800 of 2,000 Pakistani militants arrested in Jan as part of crackdown against extremist Muslim groups, provided they vow to abstain from violence and outlawed groups (M)

abstract: Pres Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe is declared winner of presidential election marred by political violence and other irregularities; results are rejected by challenger Morgan Tsvangirai, who says opposition is wary of fueling political violence, but is considering options that might include court challenge or calls for general strike; standoff and possibility of greater civil unrest leaves already troubled country deeply uneasy; European and American observers condemn vote as fundamentally flawed, and Pres Bush says United States does not recognize outcome of election; Orgn of African Unity, and South Africa and Nigeria, hail outcome; criticism from other African leaders is muted because of Mugabe's standing as hero of one of Africa's liberation struggles, and general wariness that condemning abuses in Zimbabe might lead their own governments open to similar scrutiny; Tsvangirai's claim of vote rigging has yet to be proven, but there is no doubt that government reduced number of polling places in opposition strongholds; photo (M)

headline: GOVERNMENT SETS RULES FOR MILITARY ON WAR TRIBUNALS

subjects: [u'WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC)', u'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'COURTS-MARTIAL', u'CAPITAL PUNISHMENT', u'HIJACKING', u'TERRORISM', u'LEGAL PROFESSION', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Bush administration sets rules for conducting military tribunals for prisoners from Afghan war, opening door for United States to prosecute and possibly execute foreigners by legal process not used since Truman presidency after World War II; rules, which will be made public on Mar 21, include concessions to critics who worry that Pres Bush's original order on Nov 13 establishing such tribunals had codified secret rigged system that could simply shuttle defendants to hasty deaths; rules will require unanimous verdict for death penalty, let press cover most proceedings and provide for defendants to have military lawyers at government expense and also hire their own civilian lawyers at their own expense; rules say suspects will be presumed not guilty and can see evidence against them; officials say rules on introducing evidence are looser than those in civilian courts, with hearsay allowed; rules do not provide process for independent appeals, procedure critics also sought; in surprise move, administration says it will invoke rarely used presidential power to appoint civilians as temporary military officers to be judges on review panel in lieu of appeals court; chart comparing and contrasting rules for military tribunals, civilian federal courts, and courts-martial (L)

headline: CITING 'NATIONAL CONSENSUS,' JUSTICES BAR DEATH PENALTY FOR RETARDED DEFENDANTS

subjects: [u'STATES (US)', u'MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS', u'PUBLIC OPINION', u'MENTAL RETARDATION', u'CAPITAL PUNISHMENT', u'TESTS AND TESTING', u'DECISIONS AND VERDICTS', u'INTELLIGENCE TESTS']
abstract: Supreme Court rules, 6-3, that Constitution bars execution of mentally retarded offenders; finds that 'national consensus' now rejects such executions as excessive and inappropriate; 38 states now have death penalty and 18 of them prohibit executing mentally retarded criminals, up from 2 when Court last considered issue in 1989; ruling by Justice John Paul Stevens sees 'dramatic shift' in states; decision in case of Daryl R Atkins, Virginia murderer with IQ of 59, could move 200 or more people off death row, although Court says states will have to find 'appropriate ways' to apply standard; general definition of retardation is IQ of about 70 accompanied by limitations on abilities such as caring for oneself or communicating; dissenting Justices Rehnquist, Scalia and Thomas dispute that there is real consensus against such executions; Scalia says 'there is something to be said' for abolition of death penalty, but 'nothing to be said for its incremental abolition by this court'; photos; map (M)

abstract: Pres Saddam Hussein of Iraq declares amnesty that empties country's prisons of all but 'Zionist and American spies' and some but not all convicted murderers; amnesty decree sets off mob scenes at country's nationwide network of prisons, as many thousands of inmates' relatives rush in shortly before prisoners storm out in mass exodus; Hussein's reasons for emptying prisons are shrouded in secrecy; he claims it is gesture of gratitude for his re-election; there is suggestion that growing threat of war with United States may have spurred what is undoubtedly most punitive government in Arab world toward sudden gesture of magnanimity; Iraqi exiles' view is that opening prisons is Hussein's dramatic last-ditch reach for popularity; other Iraqis suggest privately that Hussein sees need to bolster loyalty in army and state security forces, which have seen much of their leadership decimated over years in purges; foreign diplomats say Hussein may be concerned that specter of war with US could cause crumbling of loyalties that could bring government down from within; photos (M)

headline: Hady Hassan Omar's Detention
snippet: Hady Hassan Omar had made up his mind. He was going to kill himself if he wasn't released by New Year's Eve.    It wouldn't be easy. Three cameras recorded his every move. The lights in his cell weren't turned off for weeks at a time. And the guards...
subjects: [u'WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC)', u'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', u'LIE DETECTORS', u'IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES', u'SUITS AND LITIGATION', u'HIJACKING', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS', u'TERRORISM']
abstract: Article by Matthew Brzezinski details ordeal of Hady Hassan Omar, Egyptian arrested at his home in Arkansas on Sept 12, 2001, and held behind bars for 73 days without being charged of any crime; his suit against government raises difficult questions about costs of homeland security; FBI had potentially damning evidence--Omar bought Sept 11 plane tickets from same computer terminal in same outlet that Mohamed Atta had used; also, Omar fit hijackers' profile: young, from well-to-do background, computer-literate with taste for liquor and nightclubs, just like Atta; Omar, who had applied for green card, passed polygraph test but still he was held and questioned repeatedly; no one knew where or when Al Qaeda would strike next, and FBI, Immigration and Naturalization Service and other government agencies were under fire for what was seen as their failure to detect Sept 11 attacks; Omar grew despondent in jail, went on hunger strike and threatened to commit suicide; authorities will not say why they finally decided that he must be telling truth, but his breakdown may have convinced them; most important indication of his innocence may be that for 73 days government could find nothing beyond its original suspicions to hold him on; many Americans believe necessity of preventing future terrorist attacks supersedes rights of any individual; ultimately, issue will be for Supreme Court and historians to decide; Omar is among at least 1,147 Muslim men who were initially rounded up in aftermath of Sept 11; of these, only 3 have resulted in terrorism-related indictments; Omar's ordeal continues--he is broke, he has lost his job and many friends have deserted him; photos (L)

headline: To Inspect or Not to Inspect, That Is the Question
snippet: In this lesson, students will take on the role of a person, organization, or governing body with a stake in the decision of whether or not to allow United Nations inspectors into Iraq. Students will argue their points of view to a "mock" Saddam...
abstract: In this lesson, students will take on the role of a person, organization, or governing body with a stake in the decision of whether or not to allow United Nations inspectors into Iraq. Students will argue their points of view to a "mock" Saddam Hussein. In response, students will pretend to be Saddam Hussein and write dramatic monologues that he might deliver about the potential courses of action and the factors that influence his decision-making process.

abstract: Pres Bush all but sets timetable for war, warning Saddam Hussein that Iraq has 'weeks, not months' to disarm or face invasion led by United States; administration is buoyed by fresh backing for its hard-line position from 8 European leaders; says 9 nations have made some commitment of troops if war comes and more than 20 have pledged full access to military bases, airstrips and ports; Deputy State Sec Richard L Armitage, testifying before Senate Foreign Relations Committee, declines to identify countries, but says 'there's more going on' than might be publicly apparent; Pres Bush directs Secretary of State Colin L Powell to free up $15 million for 'humanitarian emergency' such as refugees' fleeing Iraq or neighboring countries in event of war; White House says Bush would welcome decision by Saddam Hussein to avert bloodshed by voluntarily going into exile, possibility floated anew by Saudi officials; Bush appears close to making final decision on war; he is expected to map strategy for next phase of diplomacy at Camp David this weekend with British Prime Min Tony Blair, his most stalwart ally on Iraq; photos (M)

headline: New Defendant in Hague to Aim Defense at Serbs of the Future

subjects: [u'WAR CRIMES AND CRIMINALS']

headline: Putting the Swiss System Back Together

headline: Kidnapping Has Germans Debating Police Torture

subjects: [u'POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT', u'MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS', u'THREATS AND THREATENING MESSAGES', u'KIDNAPPING', u'NAZI POLICIES TOWARD JEWS AND MINORITIES', u'TORTURE']
abstract: Police resort to threat of torture in kidnap-murder case in Frankfurt, Ger, has aroused intense and heated debate about means and ends; Magnus Gafgen is on trial for kidnapping 11-year-old Jakob von Metzler, son of prominent banker, then murdering him; Gafgen was arrested after picking up ransom money; was threatened with torture if he did not disclose where he was holding boy, who was thought to be alive; disclosed site and boy was found dead; presiding judge has denied defense motion to dismiss case because of torture threat, but he has agreed with defense demand that because of torture threat, all information that police obtained from Gafgen himself is inadmissable; case involves broad questions about when procedures created to prevent abuses of power become hindrances to justice; case has special resonance in Germany, where history of Nazism and Gestapo lends great sensitivity to anything that smacks of police misbehavior; photo (M)

abstract: Kirkuk, northern Iraq's oil capital, falls to raucous army of Kurdish fighters who roll into city in pickup trucks; American forces approach Mosul, largest city in north, where Iraqi commanders are said to be offering to surrender in exchange for amnesty and end to bombing; across rest of Iraq, steady battlefield gains by allied forces give way to increasing signs of civil strife, including rampant looting in Baghdad and elsewhere, assassination of Shiite cleric in Najaf and serial revenge killings of Bath Party officials in Basra; Bush administration officials seek to dispel expectation that war is won; in eastern Iraq, near town of Kut, United States marines say they are facing force of up to several thousand Islamic fighters from various Arab countries, possibly including members of Al Qaeda; Tikrit, Saddam Hussein's ancestral home, is still in hands of Hussein loyalists, including force of Special Republican Guards that allied bombers are striking with increasing ferocity; grim scenes of conflict contrast with vista of jubilation in north,in Kirkuk; to avert potential clash with Turkey, which opposes Kurdish dominion over region's abundant resources, Bush administration says American forces will soon take control of city from Kurds and Kurdish leader Jalal Talabani pledges that fighters will withdraw to forestall possibility of Turkish military intervention; photos (L)

headline: Missions Accomplished?

abstract: In this lesson, students will examine how the war on Iraq is progressing by looking at current events and comparing them to the goals outlined by General Tommy R. Frank; they then create a progress report assessing how close the coalition forces are to obtaining these goals.

headline: As Order Breaks Down, Allied Forces Pledge to Rebuild Iraqi Police
snippet: American officers in Iraq have begun working with local Iraqi officials to try to form the nucleus of new police forces, but that effort is unlikely to do much in the short term to quell the looting and lawlessness now seen in much of the country,...
subjects: [u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'LOOTING', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: American officers in Iraq begin working with local Iraqi officials to try to form nucleus of new police forces; defense officials say effort is unlikely to do much in short term to quell looting and lawlessness now seen in much of country; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld, at Pentagon briefing, says situation is 'untidy' but that everything cannot be accomplished instantaneously; defends Bush administration against charges that it has done too little to foresee or to put down outbreak of crime and violence; suggests most of violence would subside on its own after initial explosion of pent-up Iraqi resentment is spent; photo (M)

abstract: Cuba, after swift and secret trial, executes three men who hijacked ferry last week in failed effort to reach United States; gives four other men who aided in effort life sentences; Amnesty International aide Curt Goering says executions and harsh sentences recently give nonviolent dissidents contribute to climate of repression (M)

headline: Ideas & Trends: About Face; A Tyrant Disappears. So Who Feels Safe?
snippet: THE statues were toppled, the portraits defaced, the palaces stripped of their finery. But it was never going to be quite enough.    For Iraqis truly to start over, said many who had witnessed the end of tyranny elsewhere, there would have to be a...
subjects: [u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Failure to capture or kill Saddam Hussein prevents Iraqis from having full sense of freedom from his oppression and security about their future; they will have to find way to identify source of Saddam's tyranny, confront it and penalize it so that its revival becomes impossible; history offers lessons on how that can be accomplished; photo (M)

headline: Who Owns the Rules of War?
snippet: During the euphoria of the opening air campaign against Baghdad, commentary was filled with triumphal rhetoric about hitting ''legitimate military objectives'' while causing little or even no loss of civilian life. A week ago, the air war was...
subjects: [u'ATOMIC WEAPONS', u'BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'WAR CRIMES, GENOCIDE AND CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Prof Kenneth Anderson article holds Iraq war demands rethinking of international rules of conduct during war; discusses disagreement over who has authority to declare, interpret and enforce rules and who and what developments will shape rules now and in future; traces history of such rules; questions view that uninvolved parties automatically carry greater moral authority than victors; photos (M)

headline: As the Iraq War Goes On, Afghan Violence Increases
snippet: It was a good place for an ambush, a natural parapet sticking up from a riverbed within easy firing range of the road, and a warren of gullies providing cover for the getaway. The men who fired on United States Special Forces, killing two instantly...
subjects: [u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Pattern of recent violence and arrests by American forces in southern Afghanistan suggests both that Taliban loyalists are newly active and that they have had help from local officials who are supposedly loyal to Pres Hamid Karzai; map shows where two American soldiers were killed in ambush last month in Sangeen (M)

headline: Free to Protest, Iraqis Complain About the U.S.
snippet: Protests against the American forces here are rising by the day as Iraqis exercise their new right to complain -- something that often landed them in prison or worse during President Saddam Hussein's rule.     But no one here is in the mood to note...
subjects: [u'ATOMIC WEAPONS', u'BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'BLACKOUTS AND BROWNOUTS (ELECTRICAL)', u'FREEDOM OF SPEECH AND EXPRESSION', u'SHIITE MUSLIMS', u'ELECTRIC LIGHT AND POWER', u'ISLAM', u'LOOTING', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Iraqis are exercising their new right to complain, which was denied them during Pres Saddam Hussein's rule, and are directing those complaints against Americans; blame Americans for looting and ongoing lack of everything from electricity to firm sense of order, and they say they do not want long-term US military occupation; there is no sense that complaints are degenerating into violence or unwillingness to cooperate with Americans; right to complain is accompanied by other rights long suppressed under Hussein, particularly rights of Shiites, who are increasingly active, some demanding Islamic state and providing civilian militias to keep order; photos; map (M)

headline: Flawed Khmer Rouge Trial Better Than None
snippet: It seems straightforward enough. Some of the worst mass killers of our times are living freely now in Cambodia, playing with their grandchildren and tending their flower gardens. They should be put on trial.     Last month, after six years of...
subjects: [u'WAR CRIMES AND CRIMINALS', u'AMNESTIES AND PARDONS']
abstract: Human rights groups oppose terms of agreement between Cambodia and United Nations setting up international tribunal to try top leaders of Khmer Rouge responsible for deaths of 1.7 million people from 1976 to 1979; say UN has effectively ceded control of proceedings to local judges; some also object that trial will be limited to top Khmer Rouge leaders and 'those who were most responsible,' effectively granting amnesty for lower ranking killers; others say potentially flawed trial is better than no trial at all; photo (M)

headline: '85 Hijacker Is Captured In Baghdad

snippet: American forces in Baghdad today captured the leader of a Palestinian terrorist group responsible for the attack in 1985 on an Italian cruise ship, the Achille Lauro, in which an American was killed.    The terrorist leader, Abu Abbas, led a faction...
subjects: [u'ATOMIC WEAPONS', u'BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE', u'SHIPS AND SHIPPING', u'WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC)', u'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'PALESTINIANS', u'HIJACKING', u'ACHILLE LAURO (SHIP)', u'AMNESTIES AND PARDONS', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: American Special Forces in Baghdad capture Abu Abbas, leader of Palestinian terrorist group responsible for 1985 attack on Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro; Abbas led faction of Palestine Liberation Front in 1980's and 1990's and has been living unhindered in Baghdad since leaving his home in Gaza Strip in 2000; is first major terrorist figure found in Iraq by US forces since fall of Saddam Hussein's government; American officials say they have not made connection between his Palestinian group and Al Qaeda and have no evidence to tie him to terrorist acts in recent years; Abbas faces life sentence in Italy in connection with Achille Lauro hijacking and death of Leon Klinghoffer, American passenger who was pushed overboard in his wheelchair; Abbas's organization later began series of attacks against Israeli targets, but he subsequently renounced terrorism and was given amnesty by Israel in 1996 following Oslo accords; prior to US war in Iraq, Abbas publicly denounced Sept 11 attacks and Osama bin Laden, and asserted that Palestinian cause was completely separate from fanatical terrorism of Al Qaeda; in separate intelligence-related development, Central Intelligence Agency officials say their analysts believe that Saddam Hussein's government collapsed so rapidly because top aides were convinced that he was dead; Abbas photo (M)

headline: Curators Appeal for a Ban On Purchase of Iraqi Artifacts
snippet: The world's museum officials and archaeologists appealed to the American government yesterday to take stronger steps to prevent further pillaging in Baghdad and called for a moratorium on the purchase of Iraqi antiquities on the international market....
subjects: [u'ATOMIC WEAPONS', u'BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE', u'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'MESOPOTAMIAN CIVILIZATION', u'MUSEUMS', u'ART', u'LOOTING', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Museum officials and archaeologists call for worldwide moratorium on purchase of Iraqi antiquities and appeal to American government to take stronger steps to prevent further pillaging in Baghdad; array of proposals for saving and retrieving Iraq's artifacts of ancient Mesopotamian culture will be considered at upcoming meetings of Unesco, United Nations' cultural arm (M)

headline: A Job for Unesco
snippet: How do we repair the damage done? The meeting to be convened today by Unesco, the United Nations' cultural arm, is a good start. But it is only a start. The United States should ask the secretary general to give Unesco temporary responsibility for...
subjects: [u'ATOMIC WEAPONS', u'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', u'BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE', u'HISTORIC BUILDINGS AND SITES', u'RESTORATION AND REHABILITATION', u'HISTORY', u'MUSEUMS', u'AMNESTIES AND PARDONS', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'ART', u'TERRORISM', u'LOOTING']
abstract: Op-Ed article by William J vanden Heuvel says meeting by Unesco is good start toward repairing damage done to Iraq's treasures, but it is only a start; says United States should ask Sec Gen Kofi Annan to give Unesco temporary responsibility for historic sites and museums of Iraq, and United Nations should also convene meeting of donor nations to establish fund to deal with crisis; says art restoration experts should be sent to Iraq immediately, and amnesty on criminal charges should be announced to allow return of looted property; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Considers Indicting Terrorist Arrested in Iraq On Achille Lauro Murder
snippet: The Bush administration today explored ways of bringing charges against Abu Abbas, the Palestinian terrorist captured in Iraq, withholding judgment about whether to turn him over to Italy and rejecting Palestinian demands for his release.   ...
subjects: [u'ATOMIC WEAPONS', u'BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE', u'SHIPS AND SHIPPING', u'EXTRADITION', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'ACHILLE LAURO (SHIP)', u'TERRORISM', u'CRUISES', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Bush administration is exploring ways of bringing charges against Palestinian terrorist Abu Abbas, who was captured in Iraq, withholding judgment about whether to turn him over to Italy and rejecting Palestinian demands for his release; he faces life sentence in Italy for his role in 1985 hijacking of Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro in which American passenger Leon Klinghoffer was killed; some American officials are leaning toward trying to indict Abbas in American courts and bringing him to US to face conspiracy charges; Klinghoffer's family and Anti-Defamation League want to see him tried in US; Palestine Liberation Organization officials say US has no legal right to hold him or extradite him to Italy, contending his detention violates 1995 peace agreement that ensured amnesty to PLO members for acts committed before Oslo accords of 1993 and 1995; US says Abbas's capture lends credence to argument that Saddam Hussein harbored terrorists; photo (M)

headline: As War Ebbs, History, Hope and Fury
snippet: This is a story of a book, the chronicle of the violence done to this city under Saddam Hussein.     The book consists of about 200 sheets of lined paper, hardbound with a childish jacket drawing of knights and dragons. It is filled with neat Arabic...
subjects: [u'SUNNI MOSLEMS', u'ATOMIC WEAPONS', u'BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE', u'LABOR', u'PERSIAN GULF WAR', u'MISSING PERSONS', u'SHIITE MUSLIMS', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'KURDS', u'EDUCATION AND SCHOOLS', u'TERRORISM']
abstract: Book found at Baath Party headquarters in Qalat Sukkar, Iraq, contains names of every person who was arrested or vanished after Persian Gulf war of 1991, when Saddam Hussein, a Sunni Muslim, struck back viciously against Shiites of southern Iraq; book is divided into chapters: insurgents, deserters, exiles, Kurds, etc; it is record of local people hostile to regime, their family members, political sympathies, party affiliations, religion and arrest records; there are total of about 3,000 names; residents of town say at least 100 disappeared; Baath Party apparatus managed system of terror in town based on collaboration of neighbors and friends and family members; employment and children's schooling were withheld from those who refused to cooperate; Qalat Sukkar was dominated by secret police (M)

headline: Documents Show Urgent Iraqi Push to Recruit and Control Troops
snippet: Eid Ali Abbas Jaafar, an Iraqi serviceman, vowed to give his life in ''a martyr mission against the American-Israeli enemies'' or anyone else who attacked ''this dearly beloved country.''    ''I will meet expectations by fighting a hero's battle,''...
subjects: [u'ATOMIC WEAPONS', u'BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES', u'PRISONS AND PRISONERS', u'ARCHIVES AND RECORDS', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Documents found in Baath Party bureau in Zubayr show effort during summer of 2002 to mobilize cadres across country; efforts included emptying prisons in attempt to spark loyalty and recruit troops; party collected declarations from Iraqis professing willingness to make suicide attacks; documents represent important record of Baath Party culture and tactics it used to galvanize and control its security forces; what is impossible to convey in documents, however, is fear that existed between party leaders and soldiers whose lives, and lives of their families, depended on absolute obedience; documents illustrate patterns of coercion and redundancy showing conformity and discipline (M)

headline: Iraqis Confront Memories in a Place of Torture

subjects: [u'ATOMIC WEAPONS', u'BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'PRISONS AND PRISONERS', u'POLITICAL PRISONERS', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS', u'TERRORISM', u'AL HAKEMIYA (BAGHDAD)', u'TORTURE', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Collapse of Saddam Hussein government and unmasking of intelligence and interrogation centers like Al Hakemiya in Baghdad is bringing out some of the thousands of formerly incarcerated Iraqis who want to confront their memories of degradation and torture; Al Hakemiya was apparently used as way station where suspects were worked over and squeezed for information, and sometimes cash, then moved to more permanent facilities; one former detainee describes being held for five months at center, where he was hung from ceiling by his arms and tortured with electric current after being arrested on what he says were trumped-up theft charges; photo (M)

headline: Inquiry Into a Deadly Venezuelan Rally Is Stalled
snippet: Within hours of his death on April 11, 2002, Jorge Tortoza became a martyr for the opponents of President Hugo Chávez. So did many of the other 18 people killed after gunfire erupted here during a sprawling antigovernment march, a confused explosion...
subjects: [u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS']
abstract: Investigation into deaths of 18 people when gunfire erupted during April 11, 2002, antigovernment march in Caracas, Venezuela, appears to be in shambles; still, it is increasingly clear that gunfire came from both sides, as did victims; much of blame for lack of progress in bringing those responsible to justice is being placed on office of Atty Gen Isaias Rodriguez, who was once vice president and whose ties to Pres Hugo Chavez, some say, have compromised his independence; photo (M)

headline: Iraqis Tell of a Reign of Torture and Maiming
snippet: In the Abu Chair neighborhood on the city's outskirts, Ali Kadhem Ghanem answers the door to his family's house with a sheepish smile. He is a handsome man of 29, until he turns his head to reveal the monstrous approximation of an ear, like something...
subjects: [u'ATOMIC WEAPONS', u'BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'INFORMERS', u'SHIITE MUSLIMS', u'TERRORISM', u'TORTURE', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Many victims of Saddam Hussein's regime are coming forward with stories of being maimed and tortured; describe network of Baath Party informers, intelligence service investigators, secret police operatives and Fedayeen Saddam, run by Hussein's eldest son Uday, who preyed on populace to snuff out dissent; many victims are Shiite Muslims, who presented constant potential threat to Hussein's secular but Sunni-dominated government; their missing body parts--eyes, ears, toenails and tongues--are visible legacy of reign of terror; photos (M)

headline: Pull The Plug
snippet: Delma Banks Jr. had eaten his last meal and, in a controlled panic, was starting to count off the final 10 minutes of his life when word came last March 12 that his execution was being postponed because the Supreme Court might want to review his...
subjects: [u'MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS', u'BLACKS', u'CAPITAL PUNISHMENT', u'CHILDREN AND YOUTH', u'DISCRIMINATION']
abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column urges abolition of death penalty, citing death sentence imposed on Delma Banks Jr for murder of 16-year-old boy in Texas in 1980 in case that embodies many of important things that Herbert feels are wrong with death penalty in US: absence of good evidence of the condemned's guilt, irrefutable evidence of prosecutorial misconduct and racism that pervades capital cases; notes that 80 percent of more than 840 people put to death in US since 1976 were convicted of crimes involving white victims, compared with 13 percent who were convicted of killing blacks; notes that Supreme Court, in reviewing Banks case, will not address race issue

headline: Threat Gone, Iraqis Unearth Hussein's Nameless Victims

subjects: [u'ATOMIC WEAPONS', u'BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE', u'SUNNI MOSLEMS', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'POLITICAL PRISONERS', u'CAPITAL PUNISHMENT', u'IDENTIFICATION DEVICES', u'CEMETERIES', u'SHIITE MUSLIMS', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Families of political prisoners executed by Saddam Hussein's regime go to cemetery near Abu Ghraib prison to exhume remains from graves marked by numbers on metal plates; many people were executed merely because government considered them a threat; many were Shiite Muslims more active in their religion than Sunni-dominated government felt it could tolerate; thousands--maybe tens or hundreds of thousands--of Iraqis executed as political prisoners might have been unidentified forever, except that bureaucratically efficient Hussein government kept records of most everyone it killed; oldest graves in cemetery date to 1983, four years after Hussein took power; most recent are from six months ago, as threat of attack by United States rose; photos (L)

abstract: Atty Gen John Ashcroft rules that illegal aliens who have no known links to terrorist groups can be detained indefinitely to address national security concerns; rules in case of Haitian immigrant who had won right to be released on bail while awaiting decision on his asylum claim (M)

headline: As Hussein Faded, Prisoners Were Executed
snippet: They were killed perhaps three weeks ago, blindfolded, their hands bound behind their backs, then shot by a government that was itself about to die. Even as American troops neared the huge prison here, Iraq continued to execute suspected spies.    In...
subjects: [u'ATOMIC WEAPONS', u'BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'PRISONERS OF WAR', u'CAPITAL PUNISHMENT', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'AMNESTIES AND PARDONS', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS', u'TERRORISM', u'TORTURE', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Saddam Hussein's dying government continued to execute suspected spies even as American troops neared huge prison at Abu Ghraib; Iraqis have almost never learned fate of loved ones executed in Hussein's 24 years as president; with Hussein gone, relatives descend on pit just outside prison, unearthing 14 bodies of recently killed prisoners; neighbors say they found 10 more corpses on prison grounds, also recently killed; personal stories told in two weeks since Hussein's fall reveal scale of torture and killing that may surpass predictions of even his worst critics; former inmates say last prisoners at Abu Ghraib were held as spies; thousands of other prisoners there were released in Oct in amnesty declared by Hussein as tensions between Iraq and US grew; photos of Iraqis, with faces covered against stench, digging up shallow graves of executed prisoners (M)

subjects: [u'RUNNING', u'BOOKS AND LITERATURE']
abstract: Martin Hanley, actor and runner, creates 10-kilometer race throught Dedham, Mass, suburb of Boston, in honor of James Joyce; first James Joyce Ramble took place on March 26, 1984, with more than 200 people running in honor of Joyce; Hanley has added features to race: he has actors in period garb read Joyce at various places along 6.2-mile course through center of town; readings became signature of race, which now attracts more than 3,000 runners; photo (M)

subjects: [u'ATOMIC WEAPONS', u'BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Ahmad Chalabi, Iraqi opposition leader favored by Pentagon, says he is concerned that United States appears ready to admit senior officials from Saddam Hussein's Baath Party in transitional government; Jay Garner, who heads transition office, has met with some director generals from Hussein's ministries, who by definition had to be members of Baath Party; has said membership in party would not in itself disqualify Iraqis from retaining their administrative jobs, but that close associates of Hussein and known violators of human rights would be barred; Americans are having difficulty bringing order to political vacuum that followed ouster of Hussein; situation is complicated by continuing uncertainty about whether he is alive; photo (M)
