abstract: Presidents of three African nations will travel to Zimbabwe to push for talks between Pres Robert Mugabe's government and opposition leaders; South African Pres Thabo Mbeki, Nigerian Pres Olusegun Obasanjo and Malawi Pres BakiliMuluzi are expected to urge Mugabe to step aside and allow establishment of transition govnerment; outrage has mounted in their countries over reports of systematic human rights violations by Mugabe's government, including arrest and torture of hundreds of opposition supporters in Mar (M)

headline: Soccer Players Describe Torture by Hussein's Son
snippet: It was little surprise that Habib Jaafer, star midfielder of the Iraqi national soccer team for the past 17 years, stiffened as he approached the National Olympic Committee.    He had come to point out the scenes of his humiliations by the man every...
subjects: [u'ATOMIC WEAPONS', u'BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'SOCCER', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS', u'TERRORISM', u'TORTURE', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Habib Jaafer, star midfielder of Iraqi national soccer team, says he was physically punished by Saddam Hussein's son Uday every time team failed to win; National Olympic Committee headquarters in Baghdad, building now in ruins, contains torture chambers in basement; poor passes could result in player's being punched or slapped in face by Uday; other players were beaten with electric cables; horrors that are tumbling out of American-ruled Iraq exceed worst that human rights organizations had chronicled in years before Hussein was toppled; role of Uday is likely to receive special attention; while Saddam Hussein murdered on mass scale as political tool, to create fear that discouraged challenges to his power, Uday apepars to have inflicted pain and death mostly for pleasure; photos (L)

headline: How Iraq Can Get Over Its Past
snippet: Unscrupulous operators, who thrive in dictatorships, have a disturbing knack of surviving the wreckage when dictators fall, and of thriving, just as unscrupulously, under new regimes. In Japan after 1945, right-wing gangsters and bureaucrats who had...
subjects: [u'ATOMIC WEAPONS', u'BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'TERRORISM', u'TORTURE', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Ian Buruma Op-Ed article sees evidence in Iraq of old truism that unscupulous operators spawned under dictatorships have knack of surviving wreckage and thriving under new regimes; warns that democracy depends on public trust in rule of law, which cannot happen if that law is administered by former Baath party torturers; says advantage of Saddam Hussein's swift fall is that no deals were made with old regime, but serious problem is absence of untainted uniting figures; recommends having UN help set up ad hoc institution to cleanse ranks of Baathists (M)

headline: The World; When Do-Gooders Don't Know What They're Doing

abstract: Group of 650 Kenyan women who say they were sexually assaulted and in many cases gang raped by British soldiers on military assignment in their country win right to sue British Ministry of Defense for compensation; women's lawyer, Martyn Day, says rapes took place over last 26 years, and appear to have been premeditated and planned by soldiers taking part in annual excercises in remote parts of Kenya; says many of women bore mixed-race children who have been shunned in their communities; says basis of his legal argument will be that commanding officers systematically ignored evidence; Amnesty International says it has evidence that British officials had reports of abuses as far back as 1977; Day says most recent case in his action dates from last year (M)

headline: With U.S. in Neighborhood, Syria Eases Its Grip

subjects: [u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'CENSORSHIP', u'FREEDOM OF THE PRESS', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS']
abstract: Argument that Syrian government would ease grip with US in neighboring Iraq comes up against more complicated reality suggesting that future may hold something less than democratic contagion; Pres Bashar al-Assad has ordered Baath Party to stay out of day-to-day bureaucracy and decreed other changes, including amnesty that led to dropping of charges against Haitham Maleh, longtime rights campaigner; government's tolerance for political cartoons of Ali Firzat ends, on the other hand, as he gives up printing paper; cartoon (M)

headline: ARMY IS RELUCTANT TO FLAUNT PHOTOS OF HUSSEIN'S SONS
snippet: The United States holds irrefutable proof that Saddam Hussein's sons are dead, including dental records and visual confirmation from four of the deposed dictator's aides, but a skeptical Iraqi public held out today for photographs and the occupying...
subjects: [u'ATOMIC WEAPONS', u'BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'PHOTOGRAPHY', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: United States is reluctant to release photos of Saddam Hussein's two dead sons to skeptical Iraqi public, out of fear military would appear to be gloating; Lt Gen Ricardo S Sanchez, commanding officer, admits release of grisly photos presents predicament; shows photos briefly to small group of reporters; photos show battered, bloodied heads and upper torsos of Uday and Qusay Hussein; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld tells reporters on Capitol Hill that pictures will be released, but declines to say when; ordinary Iraqis remain decidedly unconvinced that Hussein's sons, who were responsible for deaths of hundreds of Iraqis, are themselves gone; United States calls their deaths turning point in postwar occupation for Iraq that could demoralize those loyal to deposed government; any hope of quick improvement in almost daily armed attacks against Americans is short-lived when two American soldiers are killed in latest attacks outside Mosul; Sanchez says four senior members of Hussein government, now in custody, including two of men's uncles, have been shown bodies and confirmed they are Saddam's sons; photos; map (M)

headline: A Prisoner Becomes A Warden
snippet: In steamy July, Cuban television broadcasts nightly shots of an empty hospital room. It is spacious and clean and has big windows. We are shown this room because 50 years ago Fidel Castro was held prisoner there.     After the failed July 26, 1953,...
subjects: [u'POLITICAL PRISONERS', u'AMNESTIES AND PARDONS', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS']
abstract: Gustavo Arcos Bergnes Op-Ed article recalls being political prisoner along with Fidel Castro under Fulgencio Batista regime and later as prisoner of Castro regime; says violent revolutionaries of 1950's were treated far more humanely than non-violent dissidents are treated today; says fitting way for Castro to honor anniversary of 1953 attack that began revolution would be to show his political prisoners magnanimity that he himself benefited from 50 years ago, by improving prison conditions and granting amnesties; drawing (M)

headline: Fancying the Full-Time

abstract: In this lesson, students consider the rights a worker deserves and research the impact of migrant workers in countries around the world. They then create public service announcements to increase awareness of this issue and address letters to individuals capable of redressing the workers' plight.

headline: Iraqis Struggle to Retrieve Goods From G.I.'s

subjects: [u'ROBBERIES AND THEFTS', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Many Iraqis seek to recover money, jewelry, cars and other property they say American soldiers stole from them; American forces have done little to refute rumors of theft, and there is no centralized system to help Iraqis recover their property or to answer Iraqi complaints; military officials say that in most instances property believed stolen is more likely to have been confiscated during raids or at checkpoints; anti-Western elements seek to exploit any hint of American misbehavior; photo (M)

headline: After Nepal Killings, a Tough King Gets U.S. Backing
snippet: This fairy tale kingdom gone awry, perched among the world's most spectacular mountains, is once again seething with intrigue and rumor, caught in dramas involving its monarchy, its striving for democracy and outside powers.     Two years ago Nepal...
subjects: [u'ASSASSINATIONS AND ATTEMPTED ASSASSINATIONS', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'ROYAL FAMILY', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE', u'FOREIGN AID']
abstract: Nepal has been holding off-and-on peace negotiations with Maoist guerrillas during unsteady six-month ceasefire; two years ago country was shaken when royal family was all but wiped out in murky attack that was offically attributed to Crown Prince Dipendra, who also died; every-shifting struggle in Nepal involves three power centers: Hindu monarchy, far weaker political parties, and Maoists; some politicians worry that King Gyanendra will make deal with Maoist rebels; United States, Britain and India, fearing instability in volatile corner of world, appear to be backing king with aid and support; photos; map (M)

headline: Rights Group Faults Police In Deaths of Women in Mexico

abstract: Amnesty International charges Mexican police have mishandled evidence, failed to question witnesses and otherwise botched probes into decade-long series of slayings of as many as 370 poor young women in Ciudad Juarez; documents what it calls 'unjustified delays' in probes that could otherwise have led to arrests; holds police falsified evidence and tortured suspects; meets with Pres Vicente Fox, urging his government supervise probes, take over more of cases and discipline police officers who covered up crimes or mismanaged probes; map (M)

headline: Rising Tide of Islamic Militants See Iraq as Ultimate Battlefield

subjects: [u'ATOMIC WEAPONS', u'BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'KURDS', u'IRAQ-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-US', u'ISLAM', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Iraqi officials and others say United States presence in Iraq is spurring rising tide of Muslim militants to slip into nation to fight foreign occupier; officials say fighters steal over largely unpoliced borders in small groups, beardless and dressed as civilians, go to safe houses and await instructions; expect broad spectrum of militants to flood nation; say Ansar al-Islam, small fundamentalist group with suspected links to Al Qaeda, forms backbone of underground network; Barham Saleh, prime minister of Kurdish-controlled part of northern Iraq, says US success in Iraq would be blow to terrorists; photo (M)

abstract: Arnold Schwarzenegger tries to inject some substance into campaign that until now has been based on sheer celebrity; calls for constitutional cap on state spending and makes clear his distaste for new taxes; appears with advisers investor Warren Buffett and former Secretary of State George P Shultz in effort to dispel any perception that he is movie star on vanity project; says one of his first priorities, if elected to replace Gov Gray Davis, would be to rein in state spending; says he would appoint economist John Cogan, outside auditor, to look at state finances; Judge Stephen V Wilson moves to keep Oct 7 recall election on schedule, rejecting effort by American Civil Liberties Union to delay vote until Mar; another candidate, Peter V Ueberroth, pledges that if elected he would cut state general fund spending by 3 percent and limit state spending to formula based on population growth and inflation; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Police Killings In Rio De Janeiro

headline: A Former Child Soldier Fights Her Memories

subjects: [u'SEX CRIMES', u'CHILDREN AND YOUTH', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'BOOKS AND LITERATURE', u'CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE']

subjects: [u'HINDUISM', u'WAR CRIMES, GENOCIDE AND CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY', u'BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES', u'ISLAM', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS', u'TERRORISM']
abstract: Op-Ed article by Pankaj Mishra says bomb explosions in Bombay that killed more than 50 people last month were quickly blamed on terrorists based in Pakistan, but four people arrested in connection with attacks were Indian Muslims, part of new group called Gujarat Muslim Revenge Force; says they may have received support from Pakistani militant outfit with links to Al Qaeda, but they were Indian citizens who confessed to bombings as revenge for state-assisted killing of Muslims in Gujarat; recalls that more than 2,000 Muslims were killed in Gujarat in series of attacks by mobs that Human Rights Watch has said were organized and protected by Gujarat's Hindu nationalist rulers; says perpetrators of these very public massacres are mostly known, but they are unlikely to face justice; says India should worry about Muslim community that has been radicalized by rage and resentment; drawing (M)

subjects: [u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS', u'SEX CRIMES', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'KIDNAPPING', u'WOMEN', u'SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS', u'CRIME AND CRIMINALS', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Op-Ed article by Lauren Sandler says life for Iraqi women has been reduced to need for security; says before his regime fell, Saddam Hussein opened doors to prisons and freed kidnappers, rapists and murderers; says result is that abduction, rape and murder have become rampant in Baghdad; says this violence has made postwar Iraq a prison of fear for women; says Yamar Mohammed, founder of Orgn of Women's Freedom in Iraq, beseeched American administrator Paul Bremer to pay attention to matter, but she has received no reply; says coalition officers must venture beyond their razor-wired checkpoints and step down from their convoys of Land Cruisers so they can talk to nation they occupy; says what they will hear is that without security for women, there will be no place for democracy to grow in Iraq (M)

headline: Senate Panel Backs Bill to Give Tax Windfall to U.S. Companies
snippet: American corporations that have deferred taxes for years on the profits they made overseas could be in line for a huge windfall from Congress.    Hoping to bring more investment to the United States, the Senate Finance Committee approved a bill on...
subjects: [u'LABOR', u'TAXATION', u'UNITED STATES ECONOMY', u'LAW AND LEGISLATION', u'LOBBYING AND LOBBYISTS', u'FACTORIES AND INDUSTRIAL PLANTS', u'TAX SHELTERS']
abstract: Senate Finance Committee approves bill that would give one-time tax holiday to companies that have accumulated as much as $400 billion in foreign profits on which they have yet to pay American taxes; American companies can usually defer paying taxes on foreign profits as long as they keep money outside United States; supporters say six-month tax holiday could lure as much as $300 billion back into US, which in turn would increase investment and create jobs; large companies have formed broad coalition to press for passage of bill and hired as their main lobbyist Bill Archer, former chairman of House Ways and Means Committee, and his former chief of staff Donald Carlson; many tax experts, including those in Bush administration, say bill would be mistake because it would validate strategies of companies that spend years sheltering overseas profits; critics also warn that there is no guarantee that companies will invest their repatriated profits in new factories or larger work forces within US; photo; chart (M)

subjects: [u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS', u'NOBEL PRIZES']
abstract: Editorial Observer by Ethan Bronner notes that Nobel Peace Prize laureate Shirin Ebadi got decidedly mixed reception when she returned home to Tehran, raising questions about how much impact prize will have; says Iran's rulers will see no reason to budge as long as Nobel committee and other groups like it can be condemned as Western meddlers; says for Ebadi's prize to have impact, she will need help from reformers of Iran and from across Muslim world to show that her work in human and women's rights is not tool of Western imperialism but central to all societies (M)

headline: Continuing the Search For Kinder Executions

abstract: Royal rule in Saudi Arabia is being challenged by Movement for Islamic Reform in Arabia, group of London-based Saudis who represent first opposition voice broadcasting into kingdom; their summons to two street protests in Saudi Arabia this month emboldened so many people to take part that police ended up arresting more than 350 people; government alarm at dissidents' influence is reflected in Ramadan-eve address in Riyadh from country's senior religious leader, who warns Saudis to shun such demonstrations; Saad al-Faghi, head of exile group, says he believes movement's Al-Islah network is reaching audience in millions because of large number of individual satellite dishes in Saudi Arabia; people communicate with his service by cellphone and Internet chat rooms; callers from Riyadh used mobile telephones to give station accounts of Oct 14 police crackdown, including arrest and beating of 65-year-old woman; Saudi government has jammed Al-Islah's radio broadcasts for five days, but Fagih is confident his engineers will restore full transmission; he says Royal Family's recently announced elections for local councils are meaningless without freedom of expression and assembly; photo (M)

subjects: [u'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', u'PLEDGE OF ALLEGIANCE', u'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', u'HIJACKING', u'LAW AND LEGISLATION', u'WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC)', u'FACSIMILE SYSTEMS', u'EDUCATION AND SCHOOLS', u'SUITS AND LITIGATION', u'FREEDOM OF SPEECH AND EXPRESSION', u'ISLAM', u'TERRORISM', u'DECISIONS AND VERDICTS']
abstract: Supreme Court rejects appeal challenging secrecy surrounding arrest and detention of hundreds of people, nearly all Muslim men, in weeks after 9/11 terrorist attacks; lets stand federal appeals court ruling that accepted Bush administration's rationale for refusing to disclose either identities of those it arrested, most of whom have since been deported for immigration violations unrelated to terrorism, or circumstances of arrests; that 2-to-1 ruling found that judiciary owes measure of deference to executive in cases implicating national security; dissenting judge said majority had 'converted deference into acquiescence' by accepting categorical secrecy policy without requiring government to show why names of those who had been cleared of terrorist connections could not be made public; Supreme Court's action, made without comment, brings end to one of biggest court cases related to 9/11 attacks; Supreme Court sets argument date of Mar 24 for one of term's most closely watched cases, on constitutionality of recitation of Pledge of Allegiance in public school classrooms; court rejects First Amendment challenge to 1991 federal law that prohibits transmission of unsolicited commercial advertisements over fax machines, or 'junk faxes' (L)

headline: U.S. Team in Baghdad Fights A Persistent Enemy: Rumors
snippet: The American project to build a stable democracy in Iraq has encountered many obstacles. But perhaps the most elusive enemy is an old phantom called rumor.    Less than 24 hours after a bombing in central Baghdad that tore the facade off the Mount...
subjects: [u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'ELECTRONIC MAIL', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS', u'TERRORISM', u'COMPUTERS AND THE INTERNET', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Rumors, however ill founded, bizarre or malevolent, present obstacle to American project to build stable democracy in Iraq; almost no tale is too outlandish to be believed by some; to counter street chatter that is not all accurate, American-led team of Iraqis gathers rumors in order to respond to them; their daily intelligence document, called The Baghdad Mosquito, is distributed via e-mail to elite group of military officers and policy planners and is posted on military's classified Web server; Iraq, which under Saddam Hussein was closed society, is ideal hothouse for rumors and gossip; presence of occupying power only adds to Iraqis' natural suspicions; photo (M)

headline: Our Sprawling, Supersize Utopia
snippet: We're living in the age of the great dispersal. Americans continue to move from the Northeast and Midwest to the South and West. But the truly historic migration is from the inner suburbs to the outer suburbs, to the suburbs of suburbia. From New...
subjects: [u'SOCIAL CONDITIONS AND TRENDS', u'LIFE STYLES', u'SUBURBS', u'HOUSING']
abstract: David Brooks article on exurban planned communities and condo villages as sprawling new landscape where American dream is largely being lived; photos; says Americans continue to move to South and West, but truly historic migration is to 'suburbs of suburbia' that have broken free of cities, offering jobs in office parks and shopping in big-box malls but no downtowns or recognizable borders to shape kind of geographic identity that humans have had throughout history; describes radically different cultural zones in suburbia as people make decisions to live with others like themselves, whether they are crunchy environmentalistsm, upscale Saab-driving professionals or immigrants from Asia; says further out are exurban places where soaring ideal involves ample parking; sees root of great dispersal in American dream of boundless possibilities, imagination and abundance, 'Paradise Spell' that is controlling ideology of national life (L)

subjects: [u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Private security companies are performing crucial jobs once entrusted to military far more in Iraq than in any other conflict in American history; Pentagon is relying on them to guard reconstruction projects, provide security for American administrator L Paul Bremer III and other officials, escort supply convoys through hostile territory and to defend key locations; company executives see clear boundary between their defensive roles as protectors and offensive operations of military, but as insurgency increases, companies are becoming more deeply enmeshed in combat, in some cases all but obliterating distinctions between professional troops and private commandos; security firms have sent force of roughly 20,000 to Iraq on top of American military presence of 130,000; most security firms' recruits are former members of American military; photo; chart (L)

abstract: Saddam Saleh Aboud, former prisoner in Abu Ghraib prison, describes his mistreatment by American soldiers; says he was threatened with rape, chained in sitting position to bars of cell for 23 hours a day, not given toilet privileges; says he was uncuffed for other treatments: douses of cold water, barking dogs, being forced into painful position with his arms cuffed to his legs, behind his back; says after 18 days of this treatment he was ready to talk, and he said whatever his captors wanted to hear; despite his anger and shame at what he says Americans did to him, he tells of some kind behavior by soldiers; as with other accounts by Iraqis of abuse, it is impossible to verify his claims; photo (M)

headline: Hussein to Be in Iraqi Custody 'Very Soon,' New Premier Says
snippet: Iyad Allawi, the tough-talking doctor who this week will become the new interim prime minister of an unruly Iraq, said Sunday that Saddam Hussein would be physically transferred to the custody of Iraqis ''very, very soon,'' probably within a few days...
subjects: [u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Iraq's interim Prime Min Iyad Allawi says Saddam Hussein will be physically transferred to custody of Iraqis within few days after Iraqis officially take power on June 30; says Hussein will receive 'a just trial,' unlike those he gave Iraqi people while in power; Allawi's comments are corroborated by Muwafak al-Rubaie, new interim government's national security adviser, who says American soldiers will escort handcuffed Hussein from his cell and turn him over to four Iraqi policemen for formal arrest before Iraqi judge on July 2 or 3; these are most specific public statements yet on Hussein's future; they seem to give Allawi and new interim government symbolic shot of credibility among Iraqis eager to see that they will have real power over their fate; Allawi acknowledges that foreign soldiers--most likely Americans--will probably guard building where Hussein is imprisoned; Allawi has won early support among Iraqis for promising tough action against insurgents who have killed hundreds of Iraqis and Americans; his authority to govern strongly will be limited sharply by desires of Americans who continue to have great military and financial sway, and by competing Iraqi political interests able to exercise power in ways that were not allowed under Hussein; photo (M)

headline: U.S. TRANSFERS POWER TO IRAQ 2 DAYS EARLY
snippet: Fifteen months after Saddam Hussein was swept from power, American authorities turned over formal sovereignty of this restive country to Iraq's new leaders on Monday in a surprise ceremony called two days ahead of schedule.    American aides and...
subjects: [u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'DIPLOMATIC RECOGNITION', u'ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES', u'UNITED STATES FOREIGN SERVICE', u'PERSIAN GULF WAR', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'POLICE', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: American authorities turn over formal sovereignty of Iraq to its new leaders in surprise ceremony called two days ahead of schedule, to foil timing of any terrorist attacks that might be in works; American administrator L Paul Bremer III hands new Prime Min Iyad Allawi note from Pres Bush indicating that Coalition Provisional Authority led by Bremer since last May is dissolved; ceremony is held deep inside heavily fortified area known as Green Zone; it is unclear how much control Allawi's government will exercise, particularly over 160,000 troops from US, Britain and other countries that will remain, or even over Iraq's own army and police force; after ceremony Bremer leaves country; hours later, new American Amb John D Negroponte arrives, re-establishing American diplomatic ties with Iraq for first time since Persian Gulf War in 1990; following formal transfer of sovereignty, Allawi and Sheik Ghazi Ajil al-Yawar, new Iraqi president, and other members of new government take oath of office; ceremony occurs 15 months after Pres Bush ordered invasion of Iraq, sweeping Saddam Hussein from power; 850 American service members have died; photo; organization chart of new Iraqi leadership (L)

abstract: Iraq's new Prime Min Iyad Allawi is getting reputation for being hard-nosed, and many people in his order-starved nation seem to be receptive to his tough style; his reputation is indicative of unusual ways in which country's interim government appears to be acquiring measure of legitimacy among Iraqi people; unelected, headed by exile and chosen largely by diplomats from US and UN, new Iraqi government appears to be enjoying honeymoon, even as Allawi has embarked on series of sweeping measures aimed at quelling insurgency; photos (M)

abstract: Peter Landesman article examines complex legal issues surrounding possible trial of former Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein, who is in legal custody of Iraqi government but confined physically by Americans; trial is likely to be most riveting, complex and potentially controversial ever carried out on world stage, but however carefully proceedings are orchestrated, many say trial envisioned by Americans might never come to pass because of Hussein's legal team's argument against 'invader's laws'; ideals of American jurisprudence--due process and equal justice under law--have no history in Iraq and there may be few Iraqis clamoring to uphold them; profile of Salem Chalabi, head of special tribunal; some critics say Iraqi courts will be seen as proxies for US revenge; photo; drawing (L)

abstract: Tension appears to be rising between homegrown Iraqi resistance and foreign Islamist fighters who have entered Iraq to fight American military; experts believe this is reason why Iraq has not had spectacular attack for two weeks, even during transfer of formal sovereignty; two groups have been sniping at each other on Arabic television and Web sites, and in interviews with Iraqi and American officials; University of Baghdad Prof Dhary Rasheed warns that there is effort to push large resistance out of cities to minimize killing of innocent people, which internal rebels find abhorrent, and that sides are merely regrouping; split is welcome news to Prime Min Iyad Allawi, whose strategy is to appeal to patiotism of Iraqi fighters (M)

subjects: [u'TESTS AND TESTING', u'STUN GUNS', u'POLICE']
abstract: Growing number of people, now at least 50, have died since 2001 after being shocked by Taser stun gun; Taser International, which makes several versions of gun, contends its weapons are not lethal, even for people with heart conditions or pacemakers; contends deaths resulted from drug overdoses or other factors and would have occurred anyway; its primary safety studies on M26, which is far more powerful than other stun guns, consist of tests on single pig in 1996 and on five dogs in 1999; company-paid researchers, not independent scientists, conducted studies, which were never published in peer-reviewed journal; photo (M)

abstract: Prime Min Iyad Allawi makes conciliatory gesture to Moktada al-Sadr, ordering reopening of his radical Shiite newspaper Al Hawza, and approves American airstrike meant to pound insurgent fighters in Falluja who have been attacking American and Iraqi forces there; American soldiers' closing of Al Hawza on orders of American administrator L Paul Bremer III four months ago was catalyst for some of worst anti-American mayhem of occupation; Allawi's two actions seen as early evidence of his stated strategy for taming deadly insurgency by making concessions to fighters who cooperate and cracking down on those who do not; although American officials say airstrike in Falluja was carried out after he endorsed it, it is unclear how much influence he has with American military; he has had to walk fine line between toughness and compromise; many Iraqis, expressing outrage and humiliation at being occupied, supported attacks against American forces; Allawi is offering amnesty to fighters who did not commit serious crimes, even as he promises hard action against those who do not cooperate; photos (M)

abstract: Saudi police discover frozen head of Paul M Johnson Jr, American hostage decapitated last month, during raid of suspected hide-out of Saleh al-Awfi in Riyadh; he is reputed leader of main franchise in Saudi Arabia of Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda; raid leads to gun battle with militants, including Sawt al-Jihad, who was on list of kingdom's 26 most wanted militants; Awfi, who escaped, is believed to have been wounded; Johnson was kidnapped on June 12 and threatened with beheading unless Al Qaeda prisoners were released; pictures of his beheading were posted on Internet on June 18; just four militants have accepted monthlong amnesty offered to militants by royal family (M)

headline: Sudan Memo; In Darfur, Appalling Atrocity, but Is That Genocide?
snippet: Appalling, gut-wrenching and vicious are just some of the terms that can reasonably be used to describe the mass killing and displacement of villagers in the Darfur region of Sudan. But does what has occurred there -- and continues to unfold --...
subjects: [u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'WAR CRIMES, GENOCIDE AND CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY', u'FOREIGN AID']
abstract: Question of whether what happened to villagers in Darfur region of Sudan at hands of Arab militias can be considered case of genocide is more than academic; if it is genocide, Genocide Convention adopted by United Nations in 1948 would require signers, including United States, to step in and put stop to it; even Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch say more evidence is needed before reaching any conclusion; photo (M)

headline: Mexicans Charge A Former President With 1971 Killings

subjects: [u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS']
abstract: Special prosecutor Ignacio Carrillo Prieto files charges against former Mexican Pres Luis Echeverria and other officials in killings of at least 25 student protesters in Mexico City on June 10, 1971; indictments are first against former Mexican president; present direct blow to Echeverria, oldest living official of authoritarian government that dominated country for over 70 years under Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI; Pres Vicente Fox's victory over PRI in 2000 freed his country to scrutinize past government abuses; photo (M)

headline: The Quest for the Nonkiller App.

abstract: Stephen Mihm article on new class of sci-fi-like 'nonlethal' weapons being developed by Pentagon; says goal is to enforce and do battle without killing; says so-called Active Denial System blasts electromagnetic energy to target that causes great deal of pain but does no lasting harm; Mobility Denial System sprays slippery goo making it impossible to walk or drive on it; Webshot entangles target in 15-foot-diameter net, and Vehicle-Arresting Net halts trucks in their tracks using netting with spikes; drawings (M)

subjects: [u"COUPS D'ETAT AND ATTEMPTED COUPS D'ETAT", u'FOREIGN INVESTMENTS', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE', u'ELECTIONS', u'FOREIGN AID', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: In five months since Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide was driven from power, tense inertia has spread over efforts to police Haiti's shattered society; armed factions and marauders have moved in; any number of groups are vying for street control, despite United Nations peacekeeping force of 2,300 soldiers spread across country, and despite surface quiet in major public places; Prime Min Gerard Latortue and his caretaker government, backed by peacekeepers, are focused on setting conditions for elections in 2005, attracting foreign investment and aid, and trying to restore semblance of normality so that rebuilding can go forward; Amnesty International has released scathing report accusing interim government and initial peacekeeping force of American marines of failing to implement security and disarmament measures; photo; map (M)

headline: U.S. Switches Tactic in Najaf, Trying Isolation

subjects: [u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'POLICE', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: American commanders in Najaf throw wide cordon of troops and armor around city's heart and announce plans to 'further isolate' militia loyal to Moktada al-Sadr; Shiite cleric has bunkered his heavily-armed militia force in holiest shrine; only days ago, Iraqi Prime Min Ayad Allawi flew into Najaf on American military helicopter and announced there would be 'no negotiations or truce' with Sadr; he and American officials now appear to be backing away from showdown, instead pursuing combination of negotiations and tightening blockade around mosque; loyalists of cleric have spread their insurrection across central and southern Iraq, raising morale of militiamen in Najaf; attacks have been made in Sadr City, Baghdad slum, as well as in Diwaniya, Kut, Al-Hayy, Nasiriya, Amara and Basra, all towns with heavy Shiite populations; in Najaf, situation is similar to events in Apr, when American commanders, confronted by uprising stirred by Sadr, built up powerful strike force around Najaf with vow to uproot cleric and his fighters from mosque, then decided that political costs of attacking or damaging shrine compelled an accommodation; American officials say that this time aim will be to constrict Sadr's fighters much more tightly, halting flow of men, arms and food, with Iraqi police and national guardsmen moving farther forward; photos; map (L)

abstract: Improbable, botched coup in Equatorial Guinea is black eye for Britain because several upper-crust Britons have been implicated, including former Prime Min Margaret Thatcher's son, Sir Mark Thatcher; he was arrested by South African police on charges of illegally helping to finance coup; two of his fellow Etonians are also linked to plot: Simon Mann, now in prison in Zimbabwe, and Jeffrey H Archer, best-selling author and former deputy chairman of Britain's Conservative Party; all three reject any role in plans to overthrow Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasoga; his government is among Africa's most repressive, but alleged coup-plotters were said to be more interested in country's oil production; plot fell apart after South African intelligence tipped off Obiang and Zimbabwe police; photos (M)

abstract: United States Federal Judge Oliver W Wanger finds retired Salvadoran Air Force officer Alvaro Rafael Saravia liable in 1980 killing of Archbishop Oscar Romero and orders him to pay $2.5 million in compensatory damages and $7.5 million in punitive damages; Romero was shot by sniper as he celebrated Mass at hospital chapel in San Salvador; Saravia was security chief for late Maj Roberto D'Aubuisson, who was crucial in steering El Salvador to right and condemned Romero's criticism of violence; Saravia, last known to be living in Modesto, Calif, has not responded to suit, filed by Center for Justice and Accountability on behalf of relative of Romero (M)

headline: TATTOOED WARRIORS: The Next Generation; Shuttling Between Nations, Latino Gangs Confound the Law
locations: [u'CENTRAL AMERICA', u'LATIN AMERICA', u'PANAMA', u'EL SALVADOR', u'MEXICO', u'HONDURAS', u'GUATEMALA']
snippet: Over the last decade gangs have spread across Central America, Mexico and the U.S., setting off a catastrophic crime wave.
subjects: [u'ILLEGAL ALIENS', u'VIOLENCE', u'SURVEYS AND SERIES', u'ORGANIZED CRIME', u'GANGS', u'TATTOOS', u'CRIME AND CRIMINALS', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS']
abstract: Gangs across Central America and Mexico have killed thousands of people in last decade, replacing guerrillas as pubilc enemy No 1 in region still struggling to overcome civil wars, special report, Tattooed Warriors; presidents of Honduras and El Salavador have revived old counterinsurgency strategies and adopted zero-tolerance laws, imprisoning young men for nothing more than gang tattoo; human rights investigators report alarming increases in numbers of young men killed by police and vigilantes; governments of Honduras, El Salvador, Guatemala, Panama and Mexico are seeking ways to collaboratte in fight against gangs; crackdowns in countries crippled by official corruption and impunity have weakened rule of law as much as they have stemmed rise in crime; prisons are filled way beyond capacity with young men waiting months to be formally charged; hundreds of gang members have died in suspicious prison riots and fires; gang members are migrating illegally to United States, bringing crime wave with them to major American cities; photos (L)

headline: China Crushes Peasant Protest, Turning 3 Friends Into Enemies

subjects: [u'SURVEYS AND SERIES', u'COMMUNISM', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'ETHICS', u'ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS', u'DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS']

headline: Foes of Death Penalty Making Gradual Gains in Africa
snippet: Foes of the death penalty say fewer Africans than ever before are being hanged, beaten, shot, shocked, stoned or poisoned by their governments.
subjects: [u'MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS', u'CAPITAL PUNISHMENT', u'SENTENCES (CRIMINAL)', u'RELIGION AND CHURCHES', u'LAW AND LEGISLATION', u'ISLAM', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS', u'FALSE ARRESTS, CONVICTIONS AND IMPRISONMENTS']
abstract: Edmary Mpagi, who spent 18 years on Uganda's death row before being acquitted of crime, is part of growing movement to eliminate death penalty in Africa; 15 years ago, only Cape Verde Islands did not have death penalty; now 10 countries have outlawed practice and 10 more have abolished its use; proponents of death penalty include religious leaders, particularly Islamic courts, and citizens who fear violent criminal activity; Uganda, which has 417 people on death row, supports harsh penalties, but has not carried out execution since March 2003; Uganda Citizen's Rescue activist Godfrey Ssebuwufu supports abolishing capital punishment; investigates cases of those individuals on death row and seeks to have verdicts overturned; Edmary Mpagi was released as result of Ssebuwufu's diligence to save innocent lives; photo (M)

headline: Priest's Arrest Fuels Anger Of Supporters Of Aristide

subjects: [u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS']
abstract: Human rights groups in Haiti and abroad are protesting detention of Rev Gerard Jean-Juste, well-known Roman Catholic priest and vocal supporter of former Aristide government; he was arrested Oct 13 in Port-au-Prince and accused of involvement in wave of violence that has claimed more than 50 lives in recent weeks; Haitian government denies that his arrest was politically motivated; his arrest is part of wave of arrests of Aristide supporters; photo (M)

headline: Unrelenting Attacks on Women in West Sudan Provoke an International Outcry
snippet: Even with the eyes of the world on Sudan, one brutality has continued: violence against Darfur's women.
subjects: [u'SEX CRIMES', u'CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE', u'WOMEN', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS']
abstract: Violence against women of Darfur, Sudan, continues even with eyes of world on western Sudan; women are insulted, beaten and raped as they try to eke out living far from home in miserable camps of displaced across Darfur; they are also threatened, robbed and beaten with whips; they are most vulnerable when they trek out to do women's work--fetch firewood; fear and distrust in local law enforcement authorities runs so deep that crimes are rarely reported to officials; when they are, victims and human rights observers say, little is done; photo; map (M)

subjects: [u'RELIGIOUS CULTS', u'DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS', u'TORTURE']
abstract: Hundreds of demonstrators from across globe have flooded streets of New York to spread word about persecution of practitioners of Falun Gong, spiritual practice of calisthenics and meditation that Chinese government has banned; they claim that government is not only suppressing practice in China, but it is using harassment, spying and intimidation to destroy Falun Gong in US; supporters of movement say 1,100 followers have died and thousands more have been tortured and imprisoned for their beliefs, chiefly in China, but increasingly in other countries; photos (M)

headline: Iraq's New Court Finds Itself on Trial

headline: Claims Over Tasers' Safety Are Challenged

headline: A Torture Report Compels Chile to Reassess Its Past
snippet: The 1,200-page document covers the period from the coup of Sept. 11, 1973, that installed Gen. Augusto Pinochet in power through 1989.
subjects: [u"COUPS D'ETAT AND ATTEMPTED COUPS D'ETAT", u'WAR CRIMES, GENOCIDE AND CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY', u'ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES', u'REPARATIONS', u'POLITICAL PRISONERS', u'SENTENCES (CRIMINAL)', u'MISSING PERSONS', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'AMNESTIES AND PARDONS', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS', u'TORTURE']
abstract: Investigative commission has completed and is about to publish 1,200-page report on torture and disappearance of political prisoners in Chile under military rule of Gen Augusto Pinochet between 1973 and 1989; report is based on testimony of 35,000 victims and details techniques and locations where torture occurred; commander of army Gen Juan Emilio Cheyre admits uniformity of torture reports betrays 'institutional' responsibility, but other branches of military remain quiet, particularly Navy; judges have ruled that military officers involved in disappearances can be denied amnesty and required to serve prison terms; Socialist-led government of Pres Ricardo Lagos must now decide how to compensate victims; photo (M)

headline: Bhopal Victims Not Fully Paid, Rights Group Says
snippet: Victims of the world's worst industrial disaster, which killed more than 7,000 people in Bhopal, India, have been poorly compensated and the companies have gone unpunished.
subjects: [u'PESTICIDES', u'ACCIDENTS AND SAFETY', u'HAZARDOUS AND TOXIC SUBSTANCES', u'CHEMICALS', u'METHYL ISOCYANATE', u'FACTORIES AND INDUSTRIAL PLANTS', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS']
abstract: New study by Amnesty International, almost 20 years after gas leak at Union Carbide pesticide factory in Bhopal, India, that immediately killed 7,000 people and sickened several thousand others, finds that survivors still await proper compensation and adequate medical care and companies have gone unpunished; says over 20,000 people have died and 100,000 people are living with chronic illnesses; charges Union Carbide and Dow Chemical, which acquired it, as well as Indian government are evading human rights responsibilities; photo (M)

headline: Actions Speak Louder Than Tours

abstract: Op-Ed article by Martin Indyk, former American ambassador to Israel, sees cautious optimism beginning to take hold on both sides of Israeli-Palestinian divide since Yasir Arafat's death; notes Palestinians are consciously making effort to favor rule of law over law of jungle, planning for first Palestinian Authority elections in many years; says Bush administration must get far more involved than it has; says Secretary of State Colin Powell's recent hasty visit raised eyebrows, since he was AWOL when his intervention was sorely needed during intifida; says peacemaking, nation-buiding and democratization need to go hand in hand; calls for strategic commitment from Pres Bush to suspend caution and skepticism that were leitmotif of his first term, in favor of sustained second-term effort to redeem his two-state vision of democratic Palestine living peacefully alongside secure Jewish state of Israel (M)

headline: Chilean Judge Says Pinochet Is Fit for Trial
snippet: The Chilean judge also immediately charged the former dictator with nine counts of kidnapping and one of murder.
subjects: [u'ASSASSINATIONS AND ATTEMPTED ASSASSINATIONS', u'WAR CRIMES, GENOCIDE AND CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY', u'POLITICAL PRISONERS', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'KIDNAPPING', u'FOREIGN SERVICE', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS', u'DECISIONS AND VERDICTS', u'TORTURE']
abstract: Chilean judge rules that Gen Augusto Pinochet is competent to stand trial for human rights abuses that occurred during his 17-year reign as Chile's dictator, and immediately charges him with nine counts of kidnapping and one of murder; orders that Pinochet, 89, be placed under house arrest and confined to his mansion near Santiago; Pinochet's defense team files injunction with Santiago Court of Appeals, effectively freezing house arrest until court rules on his appeal; all 10 charges against him stem from international kidnapping and murder alliance called Operation Condor, one of whose victims was Orlando Letelier, former Chilean foreign minister assassinated in Washington; Pres Ricardo Lagos has no immediate comment on ruling, but State Defense Council president Clara Szczaranski, who oversees conduct of government officials, welcomes judgment; latest decision reverses earlier court rulings that allowed Pinochet to avoid facing any charges stemming from human rights abuses during his rule; estimated 4,000 political opponents were killed by state security, military and police forces; thousands more were jailed, tortured or driven into exile; photos; chronology of major events since Pinochet seized power in 1973 (M)

headline: TOLL IN UNDERSEA EARTHQUAKE PASSES 25,000; A THIRD OF THE DEAD ARE SAID TO BE CHILDREN
locations: [u'SRI LANKA', u'INDIA', u'THAILAND', u'MALAYSIA', u'SOMALIA', u'FAR EAST, SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ASIA AND PACIFIC AREAS', u'INDONESIA', u'MALDIVES']
snippet: Survivors arranged for mass burials and searched for tens of thousands of the missing in countries thousands of miles apart.
subjects: [u'CHOLERA', u'RECORDINGS (VIDEO)', u'RECORDS AND ACHIEVEMENTS', u'TIDAL WAVES', u'EARTHQUAKES', u'WATER', u'CHILDREN AND YOUTH', u'MISSING PERSONS', u'MEDICINE AND HEALTH']
abstract: Officials describe gigantic undersea earthquake in South Asia as one of worst natural disasters in recent history, as toll from disaster reaches more than 25,000 dead, a third of them children; tens of thousands of people are still missing; survivors in countries thousands of miles apart recover bodies, hurriedly arranging for mass burials while searching for the missing; concern now is for hundreds of thousands of people stranded in open without clean drinking water in Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, India, Maldives and Somalia; International Red Cross and government officials in those countries warn of epidemics of cholera and other waterborne diseases that could take as many lives as initial waves; amateur videotape played on television shows terrifying scenes from several countries of huge walls of water crashing through palm trees and over tops of buildings and roaring up coastal streets with cars and debris bobbing on surface; people are shown clinging to buildings, being swept away by current, running for their lives, weeping, carrying injured and cradling dead children; images from around region present tableau of unrelenting grief; photos; map (L)

headline: Bush Nominee Plans to Stand Firm on War-Captive Memo
snippet: Alberto R. Gonzales goes before the Senate today as President Bush's pick for attorney general.
subjects: [u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'GENEVA CONVENTIONS', u'PRISONERS OF WAR', u'TERRORISM', u'TORTURE', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Alberto R Gonzales, who goes before Senate as Pres Bush's choice for attorney general, will offer unapologetic defense of draft memorandum he wrote in 2002 describing parts of Geneva Conventions as 'quaint' and 'obsolete'; administration critics have called on Gonzales to repudiate memo, which held that Conventions did not apply to prisoners taken in war in Afghanistan; in case of Justice Dept memo on torture, Gonzales is expected to offer more nuanced explanation and to distance himself from opinion's severe conclusions while offering strong opposition to use of torture against prisoners (M)

headline: German's Claim of Kidnapping Brings Investigation of U.S. Link
locations: [u'GERMANY', u'NEW YORK CITY', u'MACEDONIA (FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC)', u'WASHINGTON (DC)', u'AFGHANISTAN', u'ALBANIA']
snippet: A German citizen born in Lebanon alleges that he was shackled, abused and accused of having ties to Al Qaeda while he was held by Americans in a prison in Afghanistan.
subjects: [u'WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC)', u'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'PRISONERS OF WAR', u'KIDNAPPING', u'HIJACKING', u'TERRORISM', u'TORTURE', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Article on case of German citizen Khaled el-Masri, who claims he was kidnapped by Macedonian authorities and turned over to American officials who flew him to Afghanistan for questioning under torture about ties to Al Qaeda before finally releasing him in Albania; German officials believe his story, have verified some elements of it, and are working with Americans on investigation; Masri's lawyer suspects Masri was caught up in Central Intelligence Agency sweep involving taking prisoners to another country for interrogation because his name is similar to that of man wanted in Sept 11 attacks; photo (L)

headline: 81 Afghans Freed by U.S.; First Step in Broad Amnesty
snippet: The release was described as the first stage of a reconciliation program under which many suspected Taliban fighters might be freed.
subjects: [u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'GUANTANAMO BAY NAVAL BASE (CUBA)', u'AMNESTIES AND PARDONS', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: US military releases 81 Afghan prisoners as country plans reconciliation program under which many Taliban fighters may get amnesty if they renounce violence; Pres Hamid Karzai wants to prosecute only top leadership; most of released detainees, some held at Bagram as long as two years, deny Taliban links; chief justice Fazel Hadi Shinwari says government seeks release of all Afghans detainees in country and at Guantanamo prison, where at least few of prisoners are thought to be senior Taliban (M)

headline: Indonesia to Open Talks With Aceh Rebels
snippet: The move is intended to assert full government control over the troubled region.
subjects: [u'INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE']
abstract: Indonesia says it would open peace talks with separatist rebels of tsunami-devastated Aceh Province in Helsinki, Finland, in move intended to assert full government control over region; former Finnish Pres Martti Ahtisaari, well-known negotiator, will be involved in two-day session between exiled leaders of Free Aceh Movement and three members of Indonesian cabinet; significantly, Indonesian military, which has run Aceh Province for 30 years, has not approved Helsinki talks and seems intent on undermining its prospects (M)

They research topics related to the January 2005 election, then outline and, individually, write segments for a planned television news hour to be held and recorded during a later class period.

headline: U.S. PRODS ISRAEL FOR HARD CHOICES ON PALESTINIANS
locations: [u'WEST BANK', u'SHARM EL SHEIK (EGYPT)', u'ISRAEL', u'RAMALLAH (WEST BANK)', u'MIDDLE EAST']
snippet: The U.S. secretary of state said today that the Israeli prime minister and new Palestinian president would visit the White House for talks in the spring.
subjects: [u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'PALESTINIANS', u'PRISONERS OF WAR']
abstract: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice meets with Prime Min Ariel Sharon and other Israeli leaders, calling on them to make 'hard decisions' in negotiations with Palestinian leaders waging their own fight against militants; Bush administration officials say Israel must proceed with its withdrawal of forces from West Bank cities, its lifting of roadblocks and checkpoints throughout occupied territories and possible release of Palestinian prisoners; Israeli official says Rice also asked Israeli leaders not to undermine political standing of new Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas; Rice will meet with Abbas at Palestinian headquarters in Ramallah; her visit to Israel, coming days before Sharon is to meet with Abbas for summit at Sharm el Sheik, Egypt, heightens optimism toward eased tensions between Israel and Palestinians; but American and Israeli officials say it would be better now for United States to stand aside and let Israelis and Palestinians work together; photo (M)

headline: Charity Appeals Cross the Privacy Line
snippet: At least a dozen donors have complained after receiving letters from various charities that identified them on their address labels as Jewish.
subjects: [u'HINDUISM', u'JEWS', u'PHILANTHROPY', u'FREEDOM OF SPEECH AND EXPRESSION', u'RELIGION AND CHURCHES', u'PRIVACY']
abstract: At least dozen donors complain after receiving fund-raising letters from various charities that identify them on address label as Jewish; error has been traced to list of donors from United Farm Workers, which rented its list to Alliance of Retired Americans and several other charities; United Farm Workers spokesman Marc Grossman says his group did not use list for its own mailings, but acknowledges that it has asked company that handles its data processing to compile such information; says it may be useful for groups that look for certain demographics; farmworkers' union has mailed letters of apology to some individuals and affected charities; some nonprofit groups say other designations, including 'Catholic' and 'Hindu,' appeared in some other address labels (M)

headline: House Passes Tightening Of Laws on Immigration
snippet: The main provisions of the bill block states from issuing standard drivers' licenses to illegal immigrants and make it easier for judges to expel asylum seekers.
subjects: [u'ILLEGAL ALIENS', u'ASYLUM (POLITICAL)', u'IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS', u'LAW AND LEGISLATION', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS', u'TERRORISM', u'DRIVERS LICENSES']
abstract: House votes, 261 to 161, to approve bill tightening immigration laws in name of border security; main provision blocks states from issuing standard drivers' licenses to illegal immigrants and makes it easier for judges to expel asylum seekers; Rep F James Sensenbrenner Jr says measure, which he sponsored, is necessary to fulfill recommendations of 9/11 commission; National Governors Assn says bill places undue burden on states, and Democrats argue that matter of setting national standards for drivers' licenses has already been addressed by Congress, which ordered Dept of Transportation, Dept of Homeland Security and states to work together to set such standards; bill is expected to face uphill battle in Senate; Democrats, Amnesty International and other groups contend that tougher barriers to asylum seekers could send legitimate refugees home to torture or other abuse; photos (M)

headline: West African Leaders Spar With Togo's Army-Backed President
snippet: West African leaders summoned Togo's new president to talks in Niger, threatening immediate sanctions if he did not attend.
subjects: [u"COUPS D'ETAT AND ATTEMPTED COUPS D'ETAT", u'EMBARGOES AND ECONOMIC SANCTIONS', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS']
abstract: West African leaders summon Togo's new president, Faure Gnassingbe, to talks in Niger, threatening immediate sanctions if he does not attend; Gnassingbe was installed as president by army after his father, Gnassingbe Eyadema, died week ago; leaders of Niger, Nigeria, Mali, Ghana and Benin denounced his appointment as military coup (M)

headline: Demands Rise for Tighter Oversight on Use of Stun Guns
snippet: Some people are calling for standards governing the use of electric stun guns after a series of deaths as well as incidents in which the weapons were used against children.
subjects: [u'CHILDREN AND YOUTH', u'STUN GUNS', u'POLICE', u'FIREARMS']
abstract: Human rights groups and researchers step up calls for safety studies and national standards governing use of electric stun guns after series of deaths and incidents in which weapons were used on children; some police departments are hesitant to deploy them, but others are moving forward; guns are made by Taser International and are unregulated; since 2000, almost 100 people around country have died after being shocked, although medical examiners rarely cite stun guns as cause of death; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Calls To Block Military Aid
snippet: Two weeks after King Gyanendra dismissed the government and suspended civil liberties, Amnesty International called on donors, particularly Britain, India and the United States, to suspend military assistance. At a news conference in the Indian...
subjects: [u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES', u'UNITED STATES FOREIGN SERVICE', u'ROYAL FAMILY', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'FOREIGN AID', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Amnesty International's secretary general Irene Khan says she will declare imminent emergency in Nepal if basic human rights are not restored by King Gyanendra; calls on primary donors to suspend military assistance; James F Moriarty, recalled American ambassador to Nepal, echos Khan's sentiments and threatens to withdraw or diminish American military aid, which is budgeted at $1.5 million this year (S)

headline: Stunning Recommendations
snippet: In this lesson, students will consider what they know about stun guns and examine growing concerns for increased safety regulations. They then discuss topics relating to the control of stun guns and write recommendation letters to their state...
abstract: In this lesson, students will consider what they know about stun guns and examine growing concerns for increased safety regulations. They then discuss topics relating to the control of stun guns and write recommendation letters to their state representatives regarding this issue.

headline: SUICIDE BOMBERS KILL AT LEAST 35 IN BAGHDAD AREA
snippet: Five suicide bombers exploded their bombs in crowds of worshipers on the eve of the Shiite holy day of Ashura.
subjects: [u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES', u'BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES', u'SHIITE MUSLIMS', u'HOLIDAYS AND SPECIAL OCCASIONS', u'ISLAM', u'MOSQUES', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Five suicide bombers, some disguised in robes of religious pilgrims, explode their bombs in crowds of worshipers and at police check point in Baghdad area, killing at least 35 people on eve of Shiite holy day of Ashura; explosions raise fears of repeat of last year's carnage, when about 180 people were killed during Ashura celebrations; photos (M)

headline: Taliban Say Their Insurgency Is Waiting Out the Bitter Winter
snippet: The militants are regrouping to resume their raids after the weather warms, a Taliban spokesman said on Saturday.
subjects: [u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'VIOLENCE', u'WEATHER', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'ELECTIONS', u'AMNESTIES AND PARDONS', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Taliban spokesman Abdul Latif Hakimi says group is waiting out harsh Afghan winter and regrouping, but Mullah Muhammad Omar has ordered them to renew raids in spring; claims to be speaking from mountaintop in Zabul province, where harsh winter has killed dozens of people; attacks have trailed off since Taliban failed to make good on its vow to disrupt elections in October; denies reports that some senior Taliban have accepted government offer of amnesty (M)

headline: A Cuban Revolution, in Reading
snippet: Members of the Cuban Cultural Center, an arts group that usually sponsors exhibitions and concerts, adopted an independent library in Cuba.
subjects: [u'POLITICAL PRISONERS', u'CENSORSHIP', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'BOOKS AND LITERATURE', u'CUBAN-AMERICANS', u'LIBRARIES AND LIBRARIANS', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS']
abstract: Cuban Cultural Center in New York City, arts group that usually sponsors exhibits and concerts, adopts Felix Varela Independent Library in Las Tunas, Cuba, which, like some 100 others founded since 1998, offers Cubans alternative to official media or state-run libraries; library will carry books and magazines from around world considered taboo by Castro regime; photos; about 11 independent librarians in Cuba were among 75 dissidents arrested two years ago and sentenced to prison; center joins demands for their release (M)

headline: Peter Benenson, 83, Dies; Founded Amnesty Group
snippet: Peter Benenson's outrage over the imprisonment of two Portuguese students spawned the human rights organization Amnesty International in 1961.
subjects: [u'BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS', u'NOBEL PRIZES', u'DEATHS (OBITUARIES)']
abstract: Founded amnesty group***Peter Benenson, British lawyer whose outrage over imprisonment of two Portuguese students for drinking toast to liberty spawned Amnesty International in 1961, dies at age 83; rights group won Nobel Peace Prize in 1977 (M)

headline: Chinese Censors and Web Users Match Wits
snippet: For specialists in China's Internet controls, the National People's Congress will offer a chance to measure the state of the art of Web censorship.
subjects: [u'CENSORSHIP', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'FREEDOM OF SPEECH AND EXPRESSION', u'COMPUTERS AND THE INTERNET']
abstract: Specialists in China's Internet controls see National People's Congress meeting as chance to measure state of art of Web censorship; prior to meeting of legislators and top political leaders, authorities summoned managers of country's main Internet providers, major portals and Internet cafe chains, warning them against allowing 'subversive content' to appear online; stern instructions are in keeping with trend aimed at assigning greater responsibility to Internet providers to assist government and its army of Internet police, who enforce limits on what can be seen and said (M)

headline: Panel Backs Women's Rights After U.S. Drops Abortion Issue
snippet: The U.S. bowed to global opposition and dropped its insistence that a document being put to a vote include an antiabortion amendment.
subjects: [u'ABORTION', u'WOMEN', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS']
abstract: US bows to global opposition at UN conference on women's equality and drops its insistence on inserting anti-abortion amendment into document that is then adopted unanimously; Ellen R Sauerbrey, leader of American delegation, says US succeeded in assuring that document did not incorporate international right to abortion, and that amendment making that point was unnecessary; document is statement drawn up for UN Commission on Status of Women to reaffirm closing declaration of group 's meeting 10 years ago in Beijing; photo (M)

headline: O.A.S. to Reopen Inquiry Into Massacre in El Salvador in 1981
snippet: More than 800 unarmed peasants were killed in December 1981 by soldiers from the Salvadoran Armed Forces at El Mozote, El Salvador.
subjects: [u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS']
abstract: OAS to reopen investigation into massacre of hundreds of peasants in El Salvador in 1981, based on new forensic evidence discovered by anthropologists at site in El Mozote; 811 people, including many children, were killed; case will go to Inter-American Court if commission finds enough evidence linking Salvadoran government to killings (M)

headline: Signs of Withdrawal?
snippet: In this lesson, students research Lebanon's recent history, from the 1975 civil war to the protest of occupying Syrian troops in 2005, and create a visual timeline for classroom display.
abstract: In this lesson, students research Lebanon's recent history, from the 1975 civil war to the protest of occupying Syrian troops in 2005, and create a visual timeline for classroom display.

headline: Over Bitter Opposition, Antiterrorism Bill Passes in Britain
snippet: Prime Minister Tony Blair's new antiterrorism package allows authorities to place terrorist suspects under a strict form of house arrest.
subjects: [u'LAW AND LEGISLATION', u'ISLAM', u'TERRORISM']
abstract: Parliament enacts Prime Min Tony Blair's new antiterrorism package, which allows British authorities to place terrorist suspects under strict form of house arrest, without trial, instead of sending them to prison; passage comes as eight Muslim terror suspects are released under strict bail conditions after being held without charges or trial under antiterrorism law passed after Sept 11, 2001 (M)

headline: Taliban Trek Rocky Road Back to Afghanistan
snippet: The Afghan program of reconciliation has faced resistance in the cabinet and among ethnic groups that suffered under the Taliban.
subjects: [u'WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC)', u'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'PENTAGON BUILDING', u'HIJACKING', u'AMNESTIES AND PARDONS', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Afghan government has yet to formally announce Pres Hamid Karzai's program of national reconciliation because of resistance in cabinet and from ethnic groups that suffered particularly under Taliban; frustrated Americans have started parallel Allegiance Program working closely with provincial officials and have accepted 30 Taliban-linked fighters so far, requiring them to take oath of allegiance to government and giving them identity cards to guarantee their safety; map, photo (M)

headline: Bush Cites Political Hurdles In Plan for 'Guest Workers'
snippet: President Bush sought to lower expectations that a guest-worker program would gain momentum on Capitol Hill.
subjects: [u'ATOMIC WEAPONS', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'FOREIGN LABOR', u'IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES', u'LAW AND LEGISLATION', u'ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS', u'TERRORISM']
abstract: Pres Bush meets with Mexican Pres Vicente Fox and Canadian Prime Min Paul Martin, Waco, Tex, to begin 'security and prosperity' partnership for increased economic cooperation; pledges to continue pressing for changes in United States immigration policy, news conference; seeks to lower expectations that guest-worker program will win Congressional approval; demands North Korea return to multilateral talks on nation's nuclear arms program, but denies setting June deadline; Fox says dozen working groups will convene over next three months on issues leaders discussed (M)

headline: Putin Favors Move to Ease Strain With Big Business
snippet: President Vladimir Putin said that he favored a change in the law that would effectively end investigations into the privatizations of the 1990's.
subjects: [u'MERGERS, ACQUISITIONS AND DIVESTITURES', u'PRIVATIZATION', u'ETHICS', u'LAW AND LEGISLATION', u'ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS', u'BANKS AND BANKING']
abstract: Russia's Pres Vladimir V Putin, in effort to steady Russia's business climate, says he favors change in law that would effectively end investigations into privatizations of 1990's; says he would support law that would reduce inquiries to 3 years from current 10 years--potentially clearing dozens of so-called oligarchs who gained their wealth in questionable asset sales; photo (M)

headline: Rings That Kidnap Iraqis Thrive On Big Threats and Bigger Profits
snippet: As many as 5,000 Iraqis have been kidnapped in the last year and a half, and ransom is the main motivation.
subjects: [u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'VIOLENCE', u'HOSTAGES', u'RANSOM', u'CHILDREN AND YOUTH', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'KIDNAPPING', u'SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS', u'TERRORISM', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Thousands of ordinary Iraqis, many of them children, are being kidnapped for ransom; Col Jabbar Anwar, head of major crimes unit in Baghdad, says threat of death for collaboration with Americans is usually just way to drive up price of freedom; security officials say ransom demands range from few hundred to half million dollars; say death rate among hostages is uncertain, but note that many hostages disappear even after ransom is paid; kidnapping rings have had harrowing effect on Iraqi families, especially prosperous and educated families whose children are special targets; scattered anecdotal evidence suggests epidemic of kidnapping, especially of children, is force like no other in driving from Iraq educated professionals who are critically needed for rebuilding of country; kidnapping is contributing to national sense of instability and fuels mutual distrust--particularly because many kidnappings rely on people close to target who pass information on net worth, daily habits and other matters of interest to hostage takers; photos (M)

headline: A Good Government Is Hard to Build
snippet: In this lesson, students explore the challenges that Iraqi leaders are facing while working to create a new government. They engage in a class simulation in which they create a new governing council to preside over their school, and then compare the...
abstract: In this lesson, students explore the challenges that Iraqi leaders are facing while working to create a new government. They engage in a class simulation in which they create a new governing council to preside over their school, and then compare the issues that they faced in creating a student government to the challenges faced by the Iraqi National Assembly.

headline: Maker of Electric Stun Guns Warns It Will Miss Forecast
snippet: Taser International, the maker of electric stun guns used by law enforcement authorities, said yesterday that its first-quarter revenue would fall short of analysts' expectations because of negative publicity about the safety of its products.
subjects: [u'STOCKS AND BONDS', u'STUN GUNS']
abstract: Taser International says its first-quarter revenue will fall short of analysts' expectations because of negative publicity about safety of its products; Tasher's shares drop 13 percent; chief executive Rick Smith comments (M)

headline: Families Yearn for News of Syria's Lebanese Prisoners
snippet: Human rights groups have said that hundreds of Lebanese men were spirited across the border by Syrian agents after Syria first sent troops into Lebanon.
subjects: [u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE', u'ELECTIONS', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS']
abstract: Human rights groups claim hundreds of Lebanese men were spirited across border by Syrian agents after Syria first sent troops into Lebanon 29 years ago; say most were suspected of fighting for Lebanese Army or one of many militias that sprang up when civil war began; apathy of both Syrian and Lebanese governments before families of disappeared has long stood as testament to how thoroughly Syrian government came to dominate Lebanon; now, with Syrian army compelled by Lebanese popular opinion and international pressure to end its military occupation, calls are rising for Lebanese leaders to demand accounting of their citizens held in Syrian jails; issue is likely to be one of first tests of Lebanese opposition, which is expected to win parliamentary elections in May; photo (M)

headline: Sweden Boldly Exposes a Secret Side of Women's Lives
snippet: Sweden is trying to address domestic violence, a crime that until recently remained muffled in shame.
subjects: [u'VIOLENCE', u'PUBLIC OPINION', u'DOMESTIC VIOLENCE', u'WOMEN', u'LAW AND LEGISLATION', u'FEMINIST MOVEMENT']
abstract: Swedish feminists, who have pushed relentlessly and successfully for women's rights, are tackling domestic violence, issue muted by Swedish sense of privacy and dismissed as sort of thing that happens elsewhere; stinging Amnesty International report and startling admissions by well-known victims set off calls for new attitudes; report praised Sweden's laws as unambiguous but warned that assaults against women have spiraled upward in 15 years and shelter system is frayed; photo (M)

headline: Mother Defends Girl Swept Up in an Immigration Raid, Amid Terror Claims
snippet: The tiny store is more like a corridor off the sidewalk than a shop, and its dangling wares - $3 scarves, trinkets, cellphone covers - shiver each time the subway rumbles by. At the store, in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, a 16-year-old Guinean...
subjects: [u'IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES', u'CHILDREN AND YOUTH', u'TERRORISM']

headline: Victims of Uganda Atrocities Choose a Path of Forgiveness
snippet: The International Criminal Court and traditional reconciliation ceremonies are clashing in their response to a guerrilla war.
subjects: [u'WAR CRIMES, GENOCIDE AND CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY', u'VIOLENCE', u'CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE']
abstract: Some victims of Uganda's brutal guerrilla wars urge International Criminal Court at The Hague to back off, saying local people will suffer if rebel command feels cornered and recommending giving forgiveness a chance; two very different systems--trials of those accused of committing atrocities and forgiveness rite involving raw eggs, twigs and livestock--are clashing in their response to one of continent's most bizarre and brutal guerrilla wars, conflict that has raged for 18 years; international court was invited to investigate war by Pres Yoweri Museveni, and says it is close to issuing arrest warrants for, among others, Joseph Kony, self-styled spiritualist whose rebel troops have cut off lips, hands, noses and breasts of civilians, intending that their victims survive as constant warnings to others not to inform on them or support what he claims is Museveni's evil government; photos; map; chronology of major milestones in country's violent conflict (M)

headline: Coalition or Division?
snippet: In this lesson, students research and write essays on contemporary Italian politics and their roots to understand the prime minister's recent resignation in context.
abstract: In this lesson, students research and write essays on contemporary Italian politics and their roots to understand the prime minister's recent resignation in context.

headline: 6 AMERICANS DIE
snippet: Officials said the helicopter may have been brought down by hostile fire but there was no confirmation of the cause of the crash.
subjects: [u'ACCIDENTS AND SAFETY', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Commercial helicopter crashes near Baghdad, killing 11 people, including six Americans from Blackwater USA, security firm working for United States military; cause of crash is not confirmed, but American Embassy official says it appears helicopter was brought down by hostile fire; others who died include three-man Bulgarian crew and two Fijian guards; new reports emerge about scores of bodies recovered from Tigris River, adding to dispute over whether dead were from mass kidnapping of Shiites that new president Jalal Talabani said occurred in Madaen last weekend; police in area claim many of bodies turned up as long as six weeks ago, and American officials say they do not know whether there was mass killing; suspected attack on helicopter and recovery of so many Iraqi bodies--whatever the cause--speak to continued virulence of insurgency following relative calm that prevailed for time after Jan 30 elections; photo (M)
