headline: Locked Away Forever After Crimes as Teenagers
snippet: Juvenile criminals are serving life terms in at least 48 states, and their numbers have increased sharply over the past decade.
subjects: [u'PROBATION AND PAROLE', u'PRISONS AND PRISONERS', u'MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS', u'SURVEYS AND SERIES', u'BLACKS', u'SENTENCES (CRIMINAL)', u'CAPITAL PUNISHMENT', u'CHILDREN AND YOUTH', u'CRIME AND CRIMINALS']
abstract: Article in No Way Out series focuses on 9,700 American prisoners serving life sentences for crimes they committed before they were 18, 2,200 of whom, according to Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International, with no possibility of parole; 350 of that 2,200 were sentenced of crime committed when they were 15 or younger; rights groups say there are only three other countries that have juveniles serving such sentences: Israel, which has seven, South Africa, which has four, and Tanzania, which has one; prosecutors and activists expect such sentences to become next legal battleground, citing fact that Supreme Court took into account international attitudes when it banned juvenile death penalty in March; opinion of Justice Anthony M Kennedy in that decision, which said that teenagers are immature, irresponsible and more susceptible to negative influences, appears on mark in cases of Rebecca Falcon and Timothy Kane who are serving life sentences for felony murder in Florida, state with highest number of juvenile offenders serving life sentences, 600; juvenile lifers are overwhelmingly male and mostly black and are more likely to be in for murder than their adult counterparts; number of juveniles sentenced to life without parole peaked in 1996, at 152, and has dropped sharply since then, to 54 in 2004; photos (L)

headline: Hussein Goes on Trial Tomorrow, And Iraqis See a First Accounting
snippet: What should be a moment of triumph for the victims is stirring concern about the fairness and competence of the court.
subjects: [u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'WAR CRIMES, GENOCIDE AND CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY', u'UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE']
abstract: Saddam Hussein goes on trial Oct 19 to answer for brutalities he inflicted on fellow Iraqis, as Western human rights groups and legal experts warn that he is unlikely to get fair trial; critics say proper forum for trial would be international tribunal similar to one in The Hague, not special Iraqi tribunal that was established to conduct trials; tribunal chose case centering on execution of more than 140 men and boys in Dujail in 1982 after assassination attempt there against Hussein; many Iraqis believe that case is too narrow to answer widespread yearning for Hussein to be held to account for most savage of his crimes; political pressure to hasten trial forces tribunal to accelerate some work needed to prepare for other cases involving tens of thousands of victims, 300 mass graves and 40 tons of documents gathered from government agencies that oversaw his repression; quick adjournment is expected after opening session, possibly to weigh motions for dismissal by defense lawyers; tribunal officials say privately that they would welcome quick adjournment, sparing them embarrassment of seeing proceedings unravel as inexperienced Iraqi judges and prosecutors are exposed to pressure of trial that will attract worldwide attention; photo (M)

headline: Peru's Fugitive Ex-Leader Trying to Regain Presidency
snippet: After five years of self-exile in Japan, Alberto Fujimori promises to return, risking arrest.
subjects: [u'EXTRADITION', u'UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS', u'PUBLIC OPINION', u'POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT', u'ETHICS', u'ELECTIONS', u'AMNESTIES AND PARDONS', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS']
abstract: Alberto Fujimori says he will return to Peru after five years of self-exile in Japan to run for office again; he is wanted on four charges of human rights violations and 18 charges of corruption, stemming from his tenure as Peru's president from 1990 to 2000; if he tries to fly to Peru he runs risk of being apprehended under worldwide Interpol arrest warrant; public opinion polls show him coming in second, winning 15 to 20 percent of vote; Lourdes Flores Nano scores 20 to 24 percent in race to succeed Pres Alejandro Toledo, whose support is in single digits; Fujimori has hired Lima law firm to address mountain of charges against him that he has long ignored; his legal team convinced Peru's Supreme Court to drop one corruption charge, leaving 18; he seeks waiver from Washington to allow him to switch planes without arrest; some analysts expect him to campaign only offshore, then offer new president congressional votes in return for amnesty; photo (M)

headline: Guatemala Bleeds in Vise Of Gangs and Vengeance

subjects: [u'VIOLENCE', u'SEX CRIMES', u'MISSING PERSONS', u'KIDNAPPING', u'CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE', u'GANGS', u'WOMEN', u'FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS', u'POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT', u'ASSASSINATIONS AND ATTEMPTED ASSASSINATIONS', u'CHILDREN AND YOUTH', u'DISCRIMINATION', u'TORTURE']
abstract: New wave of violence has hit Guatemala nearly 10 years after end of civil war; authorities estimate 4,325 people were killed in first 10 months of 2005; violence includes rape, torture, kidnappings and killings; human rights groups raise concerns about clandestine social cleansing program led by rogue police officers and vigilante mobs and about disproportionate killings of women; men and boys suspected of being gang members began to disappear in past year; almost none have turned up alive; photos (M)

headline: Perfect Timing for 'The Lady'
snippet: The timing couldn't have been better for the Asian release of "The Lady," a much-anticipated new film about Aung San Suu Kyi. The pro-democracy leader from Myanmar has been freed from house arrest and the government is allowing her to run for...
abstract: The timing couldn't have been better for the Asian release of "The Lady," a much-anticipated new film about Aung San Suu Kyi. The pro-democracy leader from Myanmar has been freed from house arrest and the government is allowing her to run for Parliament in April elections. The film will be released next month in Singapore and Taiwan, although there is no word on whether it will be shown in mainland China, a close political and economic ally of Myanmar. Not unexpectedly, the film has been banned in Myanmar. When a Hong Kong journalist asked about rumors that the pirated DVD version was already available there, the director Luc Besson responded that that would be "excellent news."
